name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The next item is the debate on the question with a request for an oral answer to the Committee on the Fight against Corruption by Ingeborg Gräßle, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control (O-000021/2018 - B8-0024 / 2018) (2018/2735 (RSP)).

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: deputising for the author. – Madam President, corruption is like a disease that you can’t always see, but it systemically undermines the well-functioning of our societies, degenerates our democracies and decays citizens’ trust in politics and in the European Union. Transparency International’s Corruption Perception Index shows that there are serious problems all over the EU. But also there are huge differences among the Member States.  We also have to speak about our losses: the cost of corruption. A study commissioned by the European Parliament estimates that the cost of corruption could go up to EUR 900 billion annually. Just for comparison, the EU’s annual budget for 2018 is EUR 160 billion. Theoretically speaking, if we took a tough stance against corruption, the functioning of the EU would be free or almost free for the European taxpayers for the next five years. Scandals related to the misuse of EU funds are revealed on a daily basis. According to OLAF reports, the highest number of investigations have for years been related to Structural Funds, with most of the cases concentrated in a few a Member States, which are mostly the recipients of those funds. In some of the Member States, like in my own county – Hungary – there is systemic political corruption related to the EU funds. In others, such as Slovakia, for example, it seems that organised crime groups are benefiting from EU funds. And these are only the tip of the iceberg. As the Azerbaijani Laundromat case showed, there are serious problems related to corruption even in countries like Denmark. So there is an urgent need for action, and the EU should take an important role in rooting out corruption in all its forms. The European Commission, however, has failed to move forward over the past four years and has even taken a step backwards from its 2011 anti-corruption package by abolishing the biannual Anti-corruption Report. This was capable tool to analyse the European landscape and provided the European citizens with credible, comprehensive and comparative data and assessment on corruption, as well as highlighting the weaknesses and also the good practices of the Member States. Therefore, we regret very much in this house that the Commission decided to abolish this exercise. Anti-corruption recommendations in the European Semester are good additional tools but do not substitute the overall picture given by the report. But to credibly pointing out to Member States, we need stronger anti-corruption activity and control in the EU institutions as well. The 2011 package has also foreseen the EU’s participation in the Council of Europe’s anti-corruption group, GRECO, which could facilitate the independent evaluation of the EU institutions as well. But the negotiations on that are stalled. Still, there are a few promising steps. First is the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO). The EPPO, hopefully, will help in fighting fraud and corruption in relation to EU Funds. But it is not a sufficient tool alone. A couple of prosecutors will not be able to fight fraud and corruption fully and in a systematic way, and in fact some of the main beneficiary Member States of EU funds are not willing to participate. The second is the Regulation on the Rule of Law proposed for the new Multiannual Financial Framework. This instrument could actually play an important role in incentivising the Member States to play by the rules. But this proposal is still waiting for approval by the co-legislators. All in all, the balance is rather negative. Therefore, with my colleagues in the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT), we ask the following questions: What was the reason behind the abolishment of the EU anti-corruption report and why did the Commission not present the already-prepared second report? Secondly, the anti-corruption report and the European Semester recommendations are not alternatives of each other. How does the Commission intend to complement the Semester recommendation in order to tackle other aspects of corruption? And last but not least, to improve the independent scrutiny of the EU institutions, shouldn’t they participate in the cooperation of GRECO?

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the 2014 EU Anti-Corruption Report provided a useful overview of the situation in each Member State: measures in place, outstanding issues, policies that are working and areas that could be improved. The report showed that the nature and scope of corruption varies from one Member State to another and that the effectiveness of anti-corruption policies is quite different. It also showed that corruption deserved attention in all EU Member States. In the past years the Commission has increasingly prioritised integrity and anti—corruption, also in the European Semester of economic governance. Corruption is still a key issue in a number of states, hampering investment, efficient resource allocation, economic performance and growth. The situation calls for continued, persistent and coherent action. It is against this background, in line with the general approach of this Commission to streamline processes and focus on key issues in the relevant fora, that we considered that the European Semester, which is the main economic policy dialogue with Member States, is the most appropriate policy instrument for systematically engaging with the Member States in this area of major common interest. In March 2018, the issue of corruption was included in 14 country reports. For several Member States, the Commission underlined the need to strengthen the effective investigation and prosecution of corruption and enhance prevention. Other areas requiring improvement are whistle—blower protection, lobbying legislation, assets and interest disclosure and verifications, adequate resourcing for anti-corruption bodies, as well as transparency and public access to information. In the country—specific recommendations published on 23 May 2018, recommendations focusing on these aspects were proposed for six countries. Facilitating experience-sharing among Member States in the fight against corruption is a key aspect of anti-corruption efforts at EU level. In 2015 the Commission launched the EU Anti—Corruption Experience-Sharing Programme. It offers anti—corruption practitioners from Member States a forum for exchanging views on topics of common interest and on legislative and institutional reforms and policy initiatives in other Member States. These workshops cover topics such as corruption in the private sector, political immunities, public procurement at local level, asset disclosure, whistle—blower protection, corruption in health care, conflicts of interest, and measuring corruption and its economic and social impact. More than 300 experts have participated in the programme since 2015. These efforts go hand in hand with our legislative activity. The Commission has taken action to ensure that anti-corruption provisions are an integral part of all relevant legislative instruments. Such is the case for the recent initiative on the protection of whistle—blowers. Adequate whistle—blowing mechanisms that codify processes within public administration to allow officials channels for reporting what they may perceive as irregularities or even illegal acts can help overcome detection problems inherent to corruption. The Commission has also recently proposed a package of measures enabling the national competent authorities to access and exchange financial and other information in a timely manner. The measures aim to grant law enforcement authorities, asset recovery offices and anti-corruption authorities direct access to the information contained in the centralised bank account registers. The measures also aim at improving cooperation between law enforcement authorities and financial intelligence units (FIUs), as well as between FIUs. These recent initiatives complement other measures in areas ranging from public procurement and the protection of EU financial interests to asset recovery and anti-money laundering. The Commission also provides financial support for a wide range of projects in the field of anti-corruption under a variety of financial instruments, for example in the Internal Security Fund for Police, European social and investment funds, Horizon 2020 and Hercule II and III programmes, to promote activities designed to boost EU action to prevent and combat fraud undermining the EU’s financial interests. The European institutions have put in place a comprehensive framework of rules on ethics and mechanisms to deter, investigate and punish misconduct, including corruption and associated wrongdoings. These rules are fully integrated inter alia in the Staff Regulations and the rules on financial management and internal control. They include enforcement mechanisms and proportionate, effective and dissuasive sanctions for possible breaches. Transparency and accountability are key principles of the Commission’s decision—making process. President Juncker has established greater transparency as a top priority since the beginning of his mandate. As part of the Commission’s commitment to transparency, the Commissioners, their Cabinet members and Directors—General publish information on meetings held with organisations and self-employed individuals on the EU Transparency Register. Furthermore, on 1 February 2018, a new Code of Conduct for Commissioners entered into force, significantly enhancing the ethics framework at the political level. The modernised rules set new standards for ethics rules in Europe, for example by extending the cooling—off period from 18 months to two years for former Commissioners and to three years for the President of the Commission. As regards the potential participation of the EU in the Implementation Review Mechanism to the UN Convention against Corruption (UNCAC), to which the EU is a party, the Commission is now in the process of assessing the extent of the modifications of the Union’s competence with regard to all the matters governed by the UNCAC after the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty, as well as the legal and institutional implications of this modification of competences. It is to be recalled that the EU is a unique regional economic integration organisation and, as such, this raises specific and complex legal and institutional questions.

name: Julia PITERA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! In 2011, the Commission published data which showed that as many as four in five European Union citizens perceived corruption as a serious problem in their country. Thus, in the same year, the Commission introduced the anti-corruption package, recognizing that citizens deserved access to a reliable assessment of the state of corruption in the Member States. The Home Affairs Commissioner further stated that politicians and decision-makers were not sufficiently determined to take action to combat this phenomenon and that the anti-corruption report could become a stimulus for political will to act. As a consequence, the first report was published in 2014. Unfortunately, in 2017, the Commission did not consider such a report to be the best course of action. Commissioner! Since then, anti-corruption reforms have been halted in one Member State, while another attempted to liberalize existing laws, triggering massive street demonstrations in many cities. Public opinion was also shocked by two dramatic killings of investigative journalists tracking European funds withdrawn by organized crime groups, as well as the disclosure of politicians' ties to the Panama papers scandal. To this day, we probably do not have full knowledge of the interference of a third country in the bribing of European politicians, despite the fact that the practice was described in a report by an independent investigative body published by the Council of Europe in April this year. Commissioner! Please let me know if the Commission still maintains its position that the anti-corruption report is not the best way to proceed, or if Commissioner Malmström was right that the anti-corruption report could become a stimulus for political will to fight corruption.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the parliamentary question we are debating today deals with the issue of the fight against corruption, which is a real handbrake of economic growth in the European Union. Already in 2013, the resolution of the CRIM commission estimated that corruption and organized crime impose an annual cost of over € 650 billion on EU companies. Corruption is not only a crime against the public administration, but I would almost say an attack on the public and private economy, since it alters free competition between businesses, worsens the quality of public services and unduly subtracts funds from taxation. In Europe, despite the recent adoption of important legislative measures such as the PIF directive or the regulation on the European Public Prosecutor's Office, not enough has been done, not even in terms of prevention, de facto delegating the repression of the phenomenon only to the criminal systems of the Member States . The Commission's failure to publish the second report on corruption is perplexing, especially in view of the development of necessary new measures in this area. Among the most urgent measures, given that it has been established that there are around 3 600 criminal organizations operating in the Union and that their illicit interference seriously damages the economy, I would mention the development of a common definition of organized crime at European level. , as well as the introduction of common rules for the protection of whistleblowers' witnesses and collaborators of justice at European level. In conclusion, the Union must take a firm and authoritative position in the fight against corruption to ensure that all Member States have more effective anti-corruption policies, but also to carry out a careful assessment of the compliance of its institutions with the provisions of the UN Convention against Corruption, which has not yet been fully implemented.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, corruption is a scourge on world society and the economy. That is why the UN has concluded an Anti-Corruption Convention, to which the European Union has acceded since 2008. At European Union level we have very frequent allegations of corruption. It is estimated that the annual cost reaches 120 billion euros, while there are some who say that the cost of corruption reaches 900 billion euros. So you realize that organized crime often exploits the operation of the Structural Funds. We also have murders, executions of witnesses, journalists. It is clear that the protection of witnesses in the public interest needs to be ensured. I have pointed out many times an issue that is also related to Greece. Commissioner, there must be an audit of the funds managed by the famous NGOs for refugees and immigrants in Greece. It is literally a "party" and OLAF should intervene on this issue. This is a very important issue!

name: Wolf KLINZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, colleagues! Corruption is a cancer that threatens to destroy our democracy and hit the European Union to the core. We have just heard from the Commission how important it considers the fight against corruption to be, but at the same time that it is refraining from regularly publishing these reports in future. The decision to use the European Semester and publish the corruption situation in the country reports is not sufficient. The Member States, of course, do not want to be denounced; I understand that. But the citizens want something to happen. They see how great the damage is that they are ultimately expected to do as taxpayers, and they want this to be remedied. The populists have an easy game. They can promise a lot, they can be generous with money. But when it comes to solving specific problems, they fail. We all know that the EU still has weaknesses. But we also know that corruption is one of the greatest weaknesses we face. We have to do something about it. Member States must not be able to prevent the European Public Prosecutor from investigating corruption cases in their regions in a very targeted and systematic manner. We're just seeing this happening in Malta. The journalist who uncovered cases of corruption was murdered a few weeks ago. The corruption cases are not systematically investigated, nor is the murder itself specifically investigated. One almost has the impression that everything here is to be covered up under the cloak of silence. It can't go like that. In a year we will have European elections. We know that these European elections will, in a sense, be fateful elections that are vital for all of us. We have to see that for most citizens Europe is actually equated with their future. Europe is our future, we have no other. And that is why it is important that we bring Europe back into the minds and hearts of the citizens and especially of the youth. The time for excuses is over. This also applies to the Commission. We must not preach water and drink wine. I can only appeal: start again to systematically publish the anti-corruption reports! (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Klinz!I have a question: there are repeated reports in the media that terrorist networks are being supported from outside Europe, especially in the Middle East.You can read in the newspapers that Turkey, Iran, Qatar and various countries support such networks.Do you believe that in the area of financial markets at European level, investigations should also take place here as to who is providing the funding, whether they are Islamic groups or who is behind such influence?

name: Wolf KLINZ
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Indeed, I think that is very useful and very useful.We know - since Islamic terrorism spreads across the whole regions - that they not only finance themselves from their own resources, from occupied oil wells, etc., but are also systematically financed by some states that have an interest in forced Islamism to take placeGaining ground.It is therefore important that we gain more knowledge here, too, and ensure that our financial system is not weakened by such processes and even brought to its knees at some point.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, corruption costs Europeans an immense percentage of GDP throughout the year and it is true that if this oral question has been asked it is also because we have not had a very courageous Commission on this issue. As my colleagues have said, the production of the biannual report on corruption was suspended; There is no participation in the Council of Europe's Anti-Corruption Group, nor has an evaluation been carried out on compliance with the requirements of the United Nations Convention against Corruption and, furthermore, for example, in the recommendations of the European Semester this question appears in a very timid way. The paradigmatic case has taken place in Spain, where a government has just fallen due to a case of very serious corruption, and a few days before the country-specific recommendations had been published, in which this issue was only mentioned very briefly. We have been obsessed for years with the reform of the labor market, with the reform of pensions, and the most serious issue about the operation of the rule of law in Spain, which was corruption, hardly deserved a brief mention. I think we have to change that and take this problem more seriously.

name: Dennis de JONG
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. Thank you, Madam President. I have to say that, this morning, I was awake, but I almost fell asleep again when I heard the European Commissioner, because I have rarely heard such a boring story. We are of course familiar with all the measures you mention. We have studied this. I myself am co-chair of a network of the MEPs of the Intergroup for Transparency and Against Corruption. So we know that. What matters to us is a good discussion about exactly what all colleagues here call 'the developments in Europe', which are much worse than what we read in the economic semester, the reports of it, what does not come together and also the complexity of corruption. Corruption is not just about a properly functioning rule of law. It is also about access to facilities such as healthcare, education. It is very heartfelt and it really deserves a separate report from the Commission. And then I hear, 'Yes, we have now streamlined and it's now in the economic semester'. Well, maybe it's all wrong there. And when you hear that from Left to Right in this Parliament we all think the same, that we want a separate report, and we say that year after year, don't come up with a list of things that the Commission is already doing. I actually have the same story with the UN and the Council of Europe. I am in regular contact with the UNODC Secretariat, of the UN, in Vienna, with the GRECO Secretariat of the Council of Europe. And both secretariats say: we have all kinds of practical resources on offer to make it easy for the Commission to participate in the peer reviews. We would also like some financial support - the UN specifically says so - so that the Commission allows us to do our job. And time and time again, the answer from the Commission is yes, we are investigating and there are all legal problems. Yes, you really cannot get away with it, not even on an early Thursday morning in Strasbourg. We want a real debate with a clear answer.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, in principle, I support the questions which the Committee on Budgetary Control (CONT) has put forward to the Commission. Corruption, both political and economic, puts a huge drain on our respective countries’ resources, and we must take every effort to plug the leaks. I cannot, however, support any calls for the EU to make recommendations to harmonise laws at EU level or interfere with Member States’ internal affairs. It should only be our elected and accountable national governments that take measures and propose actions to root it out, not unaccountable EU institutions in Brussels. It is also rather laughable that the EU should lecture Member States on corruption. The irony, I am sure, ladies and gentlemen, is not lost on me, or on other honourable Members in this House. The fact that the Commission discontinued its own anti-corruption report on itself shows how seriously they take this issue. However, even then, the report did not include corruption in EU institutions. There must be more light shone down the dark and mucky corridors of power in the EU. Transparency International shows that corruption perceptions in Bulgaria rank them 71 out of 180, which is not much better than China. This again highlights why the UK voted to leave the EU. We have had enough of corrupt institutions wasting billions of taxpayers’ money at home in the UK without another tranche of it at European level. Why should the United Kingdom be in political union with these countries sending billions of our hard-earned taxpayers’ money abroad while they have lower legal standards and a frightening lack of audit and accountability over their own affairs? This, I’m sure, is quite beyond me and beyond many of you, I should imagine. We should all be working as sovereign independent states to help each other to root out corruption in our own back yards and not be forced to comply with EU laws which do not have proper democratic controls. I will listen intently to what the Commission has to say about the Budgetary Control Committee’s questions and I do hope that, even though we are leaving, the vast improvements of transparency and accountability are made. There is certainly room for improvement. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: blue-card question. – Mr Coburn, you mentioned that you do not support law harmonisation and European level actions against corruption, but what would you like to do with those corruption cases which have a cross-border nature where corruption activities are happening in different Member States, and organised crime groups are playing the game between the gaps of the independent national Member States’ authorities, and they always win this game? How do you manage this problem when the individual Member States’ authorities are not able to effectively step against those international organised crime activities?

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card answer. – That’s a very good question. I believe that individual countries within the European Union should work with each other. I do not believe we should have an overarching government of Europe making these sort of decisions. I think we should work with each other. We always have in the past, we can in the future. As you say, there are cracks through which things fall. Well, that’s for us to sort out. It’s not beyond the wit of man or woman. It’s not a complicated problem. I think that an overarching Federal Bureau of Investigations, as some people want to have it (as they have in America), is not a good thing. I think we must retain our independence. We are not a unitary country, we are many countries working together, and I think that’s much better.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Thank you. As colleague Dennis de Jong has already said, it is a boring story from the Commissioner, but it has been going on for 30 years. It's been the same boring story for 30 years and nothing changes. And Mr. de Jong has been here for about ten years and he says it every year - quite rightly by the way - and nothing changes either. My only conclusion can be: it will never change. Folks, this is the way of the dodo, this Parliament, the EU. No, two things that come to mind when it comes to anti-corruption: the debate we had on Mr Selmayr. Look, that is really corruption all over the place, under our eyes, without us doing anything about it. We let it go and the perpetrators are released with the shock, not even with the shock. Another example that comes to my mind, Mr President, is a colleague from the PPE, the Christian Democrats, Mr Bidegain from Spain, who, on a hidden camera of British journalists posing as lobbyists, asks EUR 100,000 for an amendment in to serve. We let that go too, with impunity. This gentleman is still here. So, Madam President, we have no mandate at all, no right to speak about anti-corruption at all. Thank you and have a nice day. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Thank you for listing who has been corrupt.I also fight corruption, but in your post, I miss a little about how you would fight corruption.How have you yourself contributed to the fight against this crime throughout the EP?What did you do here?How many times have you been to the committees that deal with this issue?Can you tell us specifically?

name: Olaf STUGER
text: "blue card" answer.- Yes, thank you.Good question.When you were at those committee meetings, I was talking to the voters in my country, there, my own voters in the Netherlands, where the mandate belongs.I've been here, for the past four years, to shut down this circus.And when this circus is closed, we will also get rid of that corruption.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Madam President, the fight against corruption is a key condition not only for maintaining the prestige of the European Union, but also for the EU itself to be able to function. Reference has already been made to the huge loss of many billions that could be made available for economic growth and job creation in the social and other sectors. It is of course the basic responsibility of every state to tackle the corruption that exists, but the European Union, because it has funds in the states and in the NGOs, must control and be sensitive in dealing with this serious problem. He should not wait for corruption to be reported in the press and then try to react, mainly with wishes and generalities. I close my speech by expressing my support for the struggle of interpreters and I want to thank the Greek interpreters for their full support and the effort they make to support our work. But if the European Union does not have the courage to tackle this small problem that interpreters have, will it have the courage to tackle the big problem of corruption?

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: - Madam President! I want to start with the positive today. Commissioner, the 2011 anti-corruption package is very useful. There are measures for the Member States; there are strategies to fight corruption; there are high standards of anti-corruption that should be encouraged; weaknesses should be highlighted and recommendations should be given. And now tell us: what the Commission is doing is talking to the Member States and promoting exchanges between the anti-corruption bodies in the Member States. If I tell you now - something you probably know - that we have a Member State where 1,000 corruption charges have been brought up over the past ten years and where the head of the anti-corruption unit is to be dismissed for allegedly defying the reputation of the Country is damaging to the outside world, then I would very much like to know what your position is on this matter. The fact is that we are talking about money that the Member States could easily use as co-financing for EU funding. I have not yet heard any outcry from the Commission. I believe that it is really your duty to promote anti-corruption, to publish the 2016 Corruption Report, which is rotting in some drawer, relaunch it, publish a new report and finally open your eyes and not limit yourself to perhaps closing the Member States advise or promote an exchange, but to take massive and vehement action against corruption in the member states. It is the money of all of us and also the money that can be used for the benefit of the EU.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Madam President, in the Eurobarometer of October 2017, the perception of two-thirds of European citizens was that their country was absolutely corrupt, that corruption was widespread. In addition, if we add to that the murders of investigative journalists and the difficulties that the judiciary encounters every day for more sophisticated crimes and for the slowness and lack of means they have, that leads to impunity and cynicism, which also they represent a fertile ground for the bankruptcy of trust, for the rise of populism and the radical response, which is of course aimed at our political parties, political people at all levels, officials, private companies; in short, to what is the basis of the rule of law and of our democracy. However, we know that there is a civil society absolutely dedicated to fighting corruption: journalists, police officers, judges and prosecutors, as well as officials and governments at all levels who fight every day; And for this reason - because of the risks, but also because of the hope - we need that report that the Commission promised us here in 2011, that we can follow up on trends, such as the one we do on human rights within the Union annually; so that, to fight precisely against impunity and the prevailing cynicism in society, which less and less is believed that we are capable of solving that corruption that generates not only economic losses but above all great damage to our democracy, we hope Commissioner, and of the entire Commission, that you give us the opportunity of at least every two years a parliamentary debate, here, on that report that you promised us and that you have not given us, because it is the only means of democratic control. And we don't want any alternative, Commissioner. The Commission made a commitment and we want that report and we want it now, and any other derivative will be suspicious and unacceptable to us.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! The fight against corruption is not only about prosecuting corruption offenses, it is not only OLAF or the prosecutor's office, but also, and even above all, prevention through the creation of clear laws, transparency of decision-making, effective control mechanisms. Unfortunately, this is bad at times. Numerous audits by the Court of Auditors show that the actions of not only the Member States but also of the Commission and its agencies often lack transparency, even in such obvious matters as public procurement. It is unfortunate that the Commission has refrained from presenting reports on anti-corruption activities, as this indicates that the Commission is downplaying the problem of anti-corruption and the transparency of its own activities. In October 2016, Commission Vice-President Timmermans promised that a second report on the matter would be forthcoming very soon. Unfortunately this did not happen. So perhaps it would be better for Commissioner Timmermans to stop dealing with the rule of law in Poland, and to ensure that a second anti-corruption report on the European Union appeared.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Madam President, corruption is still a disease in many Member States. We have just seen the Spanish Government fall because of massive corruption in the governing party, the Partido Popular. Spain had its worst rating in Transparency International’s latest Corruption Perception Index, coming in at 42nd place out of 176 countries. Similar perceptions can be found in other Member States’ public opinions.  Against this background, the EU should take a more ambitious role in rooting out corruption in all forms and everywhere. However, the Commission has failed to move forward on this over the last four years. We need continuity in the EU Anti-Corruption Report. The European Semester recommendations do not go into details. Zero corruption across the European Union must be our goal. We need strict controls from institutions and we need our citizens to make governments accountable.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Madam President, the problem of corruption has a clearly European dimension. This was recognized by the Commission in 2011, and the figures that account for the impact of this scourge exceed the annual budget of the Union. It is difficult to continue to think that corruption can be treated as an issue outside the real economy. This being the case, the laxity with which the Commission is addressing its responsibilities in this matter cannot be understood. By when the second report on corruption? Stop talking about the European Semester. It has already been clearly insufficient. The fight against corruption should be a public policy of the Union, a commitment to the democratic principles that we claim to defend and that should help to reduce the growing distrust of politics. The crocodile tears of a part of the establishment against the rise of so-called populisms is an exercise in intolerable hypocrisy. Unfortunately, I come from a country where the corrupters and the corrupt have viewed the state as a loot at their disposal. Spain - it has already been said - has obtained the worst marks on the Corruption Perception Index. And in the last GRECO report, my country only partially complied with seven of the eleven recommendations of this international body to combat corruption. In both cases, an unacceptable classification, but sadly it is not the only country in Europe that fails with a bang. We know the immense damage that this private colonization of the public does to democracy, not only to the economy. A part of the political class has been protected by the laws, by some judges, by some media and by the economic powers in their criminal use of public resources. However, whistleblowers have never been sufficiently protected. At this point, the question in this chamber refers to the importance we want to give to the fight against corruption and what we can say is that the Commission is far below the demands of the moment.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, there are many issues that the Commission must address and indications that it must give to member countries: the increase in penalties, the elimination of penalty discounts for those guilty of corruption, the Daspo for corrupt and corrupters, the implementation of the 2003 Merida Convention, greater protection of undercover agents and protections for whistleblowers. But I take the liberty of indicating an immediate way forward. The Commissioner is aware of the fact, repeatedly denounced by these banks, that in some countries as in my country, for example in the regions with the greatest presence of the Mafia, Ndrangheta, Camorra and mafia organizations, European funds have been the ATMs of criminal organizations , and this cannot have happened without very specific political complicity. He wants to open an ex post investigation to understand, also because this is teaching the new accession countries, with what capacity to infiltrate criminal organizations, through political connections and protections, even in European institutions and perhaps also in Parliament, have taken advantage of billions of Italian and therefore European taxpayers to finance ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, as my predecessors have already mentioned, corruption actually affects the whole system of individual states, but also the Union as a whole. How can we criticize corruption in some countries, such as the Middle East, or in Russia or other countries, when we are not systematically fighting corruption ourselves? The European report on the fight against corruption has been a personal disappointment to me. We see that the situation is deteriorating in many countries, and in many of the countries that have been named here, unfortunately, the system set up for European subsidies shows that it can also encourage corruption. We also have prime ministers here who are accused of stealing European subsidies, and the EU pretends that the problem is not here. Anti-corruption policy has not worked for a long time, which is why we have opened this issue today. Corruption is also the cause of many financial and social problems. Italy was mentioned here, here we can look at Sicily, for example, how some funds are directed. Corruption is also the reason why many EU citizens no longer trust the EU institutions. If the so-called law enforcement does not work here, Commissioner, if the EU does not sufficiently protect its interests, if it is not tough in its action and violates the rules itself, then the EU will not be trusted here. Commissioner, you know this better than I do, if the European Commission is non-transparent in some projects and if it does not itself require what it set up at the beginning, then it will not exist. I really don't want to live to see this scenario. I do not think that there is a need to tighten things up about corruption, it is necessary to increase law enforcement.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! I have the impression that our discussion is conducted with such a deep conviction that the case is right, albeit not entirely precise. Well, every case of corruption is undoubtedly a crime, but not every crime, especially economic crime, is corruption. We should separate these two things. Secondly, we should not only focus on fraud cases related to funds from the European Union budget, but on corruption in general. Another note. Corruption is not just an economic problem, as we are trying to present it, it is not just a loss of budget revenues. Corruption is the destruction of the social system, corruption is the undermining of values. People want to know that they live in a society where values ​​are valid. And corruption is of course, undoubtedly against these values. I want to direct the words that I am saying in such a direction that we should have mechanisms in place to detect corruption. And two: punishment is inevitable. These are two very important moments: detectability and the inevitable penalties. Commissioner! I must admit that you disappointed me with this presentation. You said in such a very official way: it requires joint action, we are establishing contacts with the Member States and we have an experience exchange program. So what? And you saw the atmosphere in this room: quite big disappointment that delays, ineffectiveness, ineffectiveness. We want more from the Commission and we ask for it. Show that we can do more.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: - I am amazed at this Commission's approach to corruption.We hear public mantras about the evil of corruption and the importance of transparency in public finances.And in practice, the previous Commission stopped in 2011.monitoring the implementation of the anti-corruption package, the state of play in this area has been discontinued.There has even been talk of the European Union participating in the GRECO structure.I would like to point out that, even with the most modest estimates of corruption, the European Union loses around EUR 120 billion a year.euros.These are almost two Brexit accounts.Not to mention other figures, according to which Europeans lose almost 900 billion euros a year due to corruption.euros.I will ask the Commission a rhetorical question: 'Has anyone thought that the continuation of the anti-corruption measures that have been launched should not have necessitated such a drastic reduction in the vital Cohesion and CAP programs?'

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! The current corruption index from Transparency International highlights some member states of the European Union. Because while the Scandinavian countries are at the top and countries such as Germany, Austria, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg are among the top ten, there is also a considerable number of member states in the lower middle field. Bulgaria brings up the rear behind Hungary, Greece, Italy and Malta. Transparency International also shows that corruption has increased in recent years. It is all the more incomprehensible that the Commission has discontinued its corruption report. After all, this is about a lot of money. Estimates vary, but the cost of corruption to the EU institutions can run up to 900 billion euros per year. And here the European semester and the country-specific recommendations alone are not enough to decisively pursue the fight against corruption. No! I therefore call on the Commission to lead by example, to restart the corruption report - the publication of the report - and to pursue a credible and comprehensive anti-corruption strategy.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: - Madam President, if everyone rejected corrupt behavior, there would be no corruption. But this is a utopia. Therefore, a system must be set up at every level to prevent corruption. When I was the mayor of the city and later the chairman of the self-governing region, we created such a system. We have become the best performing city in the country and Transparency International has repeatedly evaluated us as the most transparent region in the country. But beware! You will be the target of attacks by those who lived on corruption. They have money, and therefore they have strength. I am the shadow rapporteur for the new Financial Regulation. We have agreed in the committees that companies based in tax havens cannot apply for European funds from the European budget, nor can they be suppliers for such contracts. The Council did not agree in the trialogues. At the same time, it is clear that companies that do not pay taxes will beat fair competition. How can it be moral and also legal if someone does not pay taxes and then wins the contracts that make those who pay taxes fairly? Dutch Prime Minister Mark Rutte yesterday, as a reason why Romania and Bulgaria can not be in the Schengen area, said there was high corruption. And that has nothing to do with corruption if, with the blessing of the government, there is a system that lives off tax evasion and tax avoidance? Such a system affects and robs all honest taxpayers, public finances and social spending. It threatens macroeconomic stability, social cohesion and public confidence in the European institutions. The only way, Commissioner, dear friends, is to create a system at all levels that will not allow such practices.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: - Madam President, Commissioner. Organized criminal groups are looting EU funds and then gaining influence in decision-making, creating a captive state, “state capture”. There are also parties in this House who use EU funds irregularly and then use the opportunities to create anti-EU sentiment. In Hungary, the funds provided by the EU are obtained in a corrupt way by close-to-government oligarchs, who then buy press products independent of these sources, which are put at the service of anti-EU government propaganda. Understand that corruption is not just a financial loss for the European Union and taxpayers, but it directly undermines the democratic rule of law around us and the European Union, the institutions of the European Union. If the Commission does not take firm action against corruption in both the Member States and the Union, we will lose everything we owe to the democratic rule of law and the European Union.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Madam President, turning to the Commissioner, let me say that the one and only report so far defines corruption in a broad sense as any ‘abuse of power for private gain’. Now, this is the point of departure, on which Commissioner Malmström, when introducing that report in February 2014, said: ‘We are simply not doing enough. That is true of all Member States. Existing laws and policies are not enforced enough.’  Bulgaria was mentioned yesterday by Prime Minister Rutte; but in that report it says that the Netherlands lacks transparency in the financing of political parties, no evidence is forthcoming of foreign bribery being tackled adequately and there is not a focus on prosecuting corruption in international business transactions. So, instead of depending on perceptions, the Commission should provide us with a clear, analytical report stating the facts, so that there is no such totally unacceptable shaming of one or another country.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, the question to the Commission is pertinent. We all want to stop having corruption. Everyone says, I believe in the good faith of my colleagues in the European Parliament. But, Commissioner, before pointing the finger at one country or another, don't you think we should have - as has been said here - a common definition of crime, common tools for measuring crime, for control, for information, for information? correct, because we can't make decisions about information we don't know how to collect. Commissioner, you said we need to protect whistleblowers. I agree. But what do you say about what is happening in my country, where, after some unjustifiable whistleblowers have denounced, prosecutors have tortured dozens of people, who have now been acquitted after trials. I believe that the solution is, Commissioner, not to stigmatize a country, but to establish these measures. And I say one more thing. The Commission often says - and it has been discussed today - that you will have conditionality for European funds. But Mr Juncker did not answer, nor did you, which are the instruments with which you measure the rule of law, in order not to make this assessment subjective in the granting of European funds.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, corruption continues to be one of the toughest challenges for Europe, a phenomenon that costs the European economy around EUR 120 billion a year. Although Member States have taken a lot of initiative over the past four years, the results obtained appear to be mixed and fallacious, and much more should be done to prevent and punish corruption. The anti-corruption report that the Commission published in 2014 could have been an excellent tool to ensure monitoring of the state of corruption in the European Union. Unfortunately, however, the Commission did not see fit to follow up on this initiative. We therefore asked, without receiving a response, for a common definition of the crime of corruption, a horizontal definition of a public official and the most courageous legislative proposals on the subject. Finally, I still consider the protection of the category of investigative journalists, who constitute a potentially devastating weapon to arrive at the truth, too weak. As such, these journalists must be better protected, representing a category at risk, as sadly demonstrated by the murders of Caruana Galizia and Jan Kuciak.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Madam President, indeed, corruption not only detracts important resources from citizens, but undermines trust, erodes democracy and institutions. It is important to mobilize and find resources to fight corruption, identify it and punish it. We understand, as the commissioner has said, that transparency and accountability are fundamental tools in the fight against corruption, as well as the establishment of fair trials, dissuasive sentences and protection of whistleblowers. In its latest report, the Council of Europe Group of States Against Corruption says that not only have there been no progress, but we have had setbacks. The case of my country has been mentioned here, where, by the way, yesterday a minister of the new Government resigned only after five days of being in the exercise of his mandate. However, this Group and this report of the Group of States against Corruption, says that in the legal-criminal sphere of the fight against corruption, significant progress has been made in my country, through the law that deals with the aspects economic and financial policies of political parties, the law that establishes the statute of the senior official, the reform of the Penal Code or the comprehensive law to combat corruption and protection of informants. In this sense, Commissioner, we encourage you to involve the Commission in the work of this Group of the Council of Europe, we also encourage you to present the report that the Commission has been making and we understand that the work of the Commission is also the to present initiatives, raise and highlight the shortcomings that exist and, at the same time, promote recommendations that are aimed at fighting against this scourge and this scourge that is corruption.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, in the 2009-2014 term I had the honor of chairing the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. The Lisbon Treaty entered into force. And from that committee we urge the then Commissioner Malmström to implement a strategy against corruption, but also a report that we debate here every two years. Unfulfilled since 2011. And the reasons have only grown. There is the criminal basis of Article 83 of the Lisbon Treaty, which is what determines that there is a serious transnational crime, corruption, in which this Parliament is a legislator. Second, the stratospheric volume. The budget of the European Union matters, but it needs a map, because in each country there are specific forms of corruption that also have to be fought with unique instruments. But, finally, and most importantly, because it has a political impact, because there is a satiety and malaise in European society. It has determined nothing less than, for the first time in Spain, a motion of censure based on annoyance against corruption has been the winner. Change the political map. Therefore, Commissioner, put the European Union at the head of the European Group Against Corruption, GRECO, and of compliance with the United Nations Convention against Corruption.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President!Ladies and gentlemen,A few months ago, European public opinion was shocked by the news of the charges against the former French president for taking power in 2007 thanks to funding from foreign, illegally obtained funds.Of course, the French justice system is verifying these allegations.But I have a specific question for the European Commission and I am asking for a clear answer.I will treat the lack of an answer as a negative answer, as a simple statement - no.Has the European Commission become interested in these allegations?Because it is about the very essence of democracy, not about some reprehensible and scandalous private benefits, but about the confiscation of public authority.Moreover, it is one of the constructors of this Union, which is functioning today, one of the promoters of the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: - Commissioner, some of my colleagues in this Parliament have criticized the Commission for its supposed lack of interest in fighting corruption. I don't know whether these criticisms are just or unfair. But there is one that is just to do here and now. This Parliament is not interested in fighting corruption. Just look at the number of deputies who attended this debate, just look at the front rows of the different political benches. That said, I have to tell you this: the worst form of corruption is political corruption. There are clear signs in many Member States, and even in the institutions of the Union, that many political decisions are made not in the public interest, but because they serve the private interests of those who make them. Many political decisions are made so that the decision maker can have good jobs after leaving, leaving these positions. In many countries, Commissioner, Madam President, it is more dangerous to denounce corruption than to practice it.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: - Madam President, corruption is the B-side of the lack of democracy. Commissioner, do you know who M. Rajoy was? He appears in the papers of the Gürtel case on the corruption of the Popular Party. By the way, only one of your deputies is present today - you can see what corruption interests them - and I am referring to the Spanish Popular Party. He was the president, who has fallen by a vote of no confidence. It was not necessary to know what the sentence in the Gürtel case said to know that the PP was corrupt in Spain. And, meanwhile, the European Commission looked the other way. In 2017, the Spanish State obtained the worst result in Transparency International's corruption perception index and, these days, we know that a member of the royal family is also going to jail. 1,700 cases, 500 accused and only 20 in jail. And what about the use of European funds, Commissioner. The Commission already warned in 2014, 2015 and 2016 that public procurement processes had an extra cost of € 13 billion. We need more European control, but also protect whistleblowers from corruption. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure)).

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: blue card question.- Madam President, Mrs Miranda, I find the statements you have made here regrettable.I believe that bringing the affairs of our country and airing them in the European Parliament does not dignify the debates in this Chamber.There is a commission of inquiry in the Congress of Deputies, another in the Senate, and the courts of our country do their job.Here we could put the fan policy and transfer other cases of corruption that have occurred in the country.It seems to me that your attitude, Mrs. Miranda, clearly shows a sectarian manipulation of the institutions.

name: Ana Maria MIRANDA PAZ
text: "blue card" response.- Look, any European issue related to corruption can be brought to this House.We are representatives of our peoples and, therefore, if the case of corruption is the concern of the citizens of our peoples, it can be brought.And, furthermore, you are not an example of anything, you are not a champion of anything, you are being the shame of Europe.So, bring an issue of this caliber here, because it is what corresponds, because it is the concern in the CIS barometer of Spanish citizens and, therefore, I, who represent the Galician people, but also many Spanish citizensthey have voted for us in the rest of the state — I have an obligation to bring him here.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight against organized crime and corruption cannot be carried out effectively without appropriate tools at the international level. At a European level, people move too slowly and find it hard to adapt quickly to new technologies, which, on the other hand, crime is able to fully exploit. The operational network for the exchange of information between law enforcement agencies must be implemented under the leadership of Europol. Administrative, judicial and police cooperation throughout the territory of the Union must be enhanced, aiming at an effective synergy between the European Judicial Network, Europol and Eurojust, and we will have to wait another three years to understand the role that the European Public Prosecutor will be able to carve out recently established. In this context, it therefore appears scandalous that the Commission, despite the declaration of Commissioner Timmermans of October 2016, is interrupting the European Union report on the fight against corruption, the only tool capable of providing European citizens with a credible comparative assessment. and to promote high standards in the fight against corruption.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Ms. President!It is also time to adapt to the new methods of the perpetrators and to their unbridledness.The European Union is already facing the challenge of a new type of corruption, more unbridled and now systematic, such as, in the practice of the Orbán government, abuses for the personal enrichment of those in power, possibly surrounded by legislation.It is the duty of the Commission, but even more so of the European Council, to deal with the increasingly shameless government corruption in the interests of Hungarian and other European taxpayers, who should finally take full political weight against corrupt governments and politicians.Hungarian and other European taxpayers rightly expect this and will hold the European institutions to account.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: - Madam President, some, like Mrs. Miranda, come here and their mouths fill up talking about the corruption of others.Could you explain to us, Mrs. Miranda, the Melide case ―the case of your party, the Galician Nationalist Bloc―, where a mayor of your party was immersed in corruption, a shameful case in her region, not a country, Galicia, of whichit's your political party, Mrs. Miranda.That does not matter to you, you look at the corruption of others.Look inside yourself to talk about others, do not fill yourself up ... To talk about the Popular Party, the Popular Party government, which has been exemplary, you have to wash your mouth, Mrs. Miranda.

name: Carlos ITURGAIZ
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first, as a general message, let me convey to you that the European Commission is still committed to fight corruption and corruption activities and wrong-doings at European level. Let me reflect on the probably three most frequently asked questions during the debate. The first was on the self-standing EU anti-corruption report. While the EU anti-corruption report provided a useful overview of the situation, streamlined coverage in the European semester of economic governance, which is the main economic policy dialogue between the Member States and the European Union institutions, appears to be an equally efficient way to address the matter and is in line with the general approach of this Commission to streamline processes and focus on key issues in the relevant fora. Others raised the question about OLAF activities and the fight against corruption at a practical level. Let me say that the OLAF management will enter into detail of their achievements for the year, where I am pleased to see the office has once again delivered tangible results for taxpayers. 197 investigations concluded, over 300 recommendations issued and significant recoveries recommended to the EU budget, stemming in particular from the conclusion of major under-valuation fraud cases. The money we get back in this context can be used to serve European citizens and to promote growth and jobs. OLAF was also able to further reduce the duration of its investigation to 17.6 months on average, despite its limited resources. This speaks for the commitment of OLAF staff to getting the job done. In 2017, OLAF activities brought a significant contribution to protecting the revenue side of the EU budget, with a string of large cases concerning the under-valuation of goods at import. This is important work; any gaps in the legislative setting or operational capacity of customs administrations to function across borders are quickly exploited by organised criminal groups. In this context, due to its ability to operate transnationally and to gather and share information, OLAF plays a crucial role in preventing and tackling revenue fraud, as well as in assisting national customs administrations in their challenging work. Last but not least, the European Commission’s participation in UNCAC. The review of implementation of the United Nations Convention on Anti-Corruption (UNCAC) plays an important role in the global fight against corruption. The review helps us assess where we stand globally and what gaps need to be addressed. While being fully committed and active in fighting corruption at EU and global level, the European Union is in the process of assessing the full extent of the modifications of the Union’s competence with regard to all the matters governed by UNCAC after entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty. One aspect that needs to be kept in mind is that the Convention is binding on all EU institutions, and therefore the scope of the UNCAC review would not be limited to the Commission but would extend to the other institutions as well.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Laura FERRARA
text: in writing. - I am pleased that this question has come to plenary, which reiterates what the European Parliament has already denounced with the resolution on the fight against corruption of 25 October 2016, of which I was rapporteur. It is not clear why the negotiations on joining GRECO are blocked, much less the Commission's decision not to present the report on the fight against corruption. The doubt arises that the current leaders of the European institutions are not very interested in the issue. I would like to remind you, however, that the costs of corruption are very high and cannot be quantified only in economic terms. Corruption undermines citizens' trust in democratic institutions and the rule of law and, by draining resources, has a negative impact on the quality of public services. Corruption phenomena have even been denounced in the management of the migratory crisis in the Mediterranean, to the point of requiring authoritative and effective solutions, to combat in the field, behaviors that have called into question the credibility of the reception policies, supported up to now, with bankruptcy results. from the European Union.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: written. - Corruption is a serious problem in the EU. According to various estimates, financial losses amount to EUR 120-990 billion per year. Traditionally, the Nordic countries have done well in various comparisons of corruption, but the risk of corruption in these countries should not be underestimated either. Structural hidden corruption and good brother networks based on counter-services in particular are problematic. In addition, too close relationships between politicians and civil servants in business and the associated revolving door phenomenon are harmful activities. Politically appointed appointments are also socially destructive forms of corruption where corruption is open. Such actions erode public confidence in the political system, which contributes to low turnout in the various elections. Uncertainties in election financing also increase the risk of corruption. Large monetary donations to parties and candidates are aimed at influencing the direction of politics and possibly even buying the desired decisions. For example, according to Finnish election financing legislation, monetary donations of up to EUR 1,499 can be made to a campaign of a European candidate without the need to state the name of the donor in the election financing declaration. In my view, this is in some way at odds with the Code of Conduct for Members of the European Parliament, which requires all gifts in excess of EUR 150 to be reported. Transparency of public authorities and disclosure of information are important in tackling corruption. Reporters of abuse must be effectively protected and have appropriate reporting channels to ensure anonymity. In addition, strengthening an impartial, financially independent and free media and supporting high-quality investigative journalism are important factors in tackling all forms of corruption.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - Although the EU and the Member States have so far taken a number of measures and instruments to prevent and spread corruption and illegal cash flows, I think that corruption continues to have a negative impact on all areas of our public life. We often talk about corruption in the use of Eurofunds, about corruption in public administration, there are even reports of corrupt behavior of top government officials. A few years ago, we in the EP plenary talked about the corruption that has affected sport, the sector that should be the most fair play. Corruption is all around us and we are used to many acts of corruption. It is therefore important for the Commission to report annually to the EP, the elected representatives of the EU population, on the state of corruption in the EU, but also on measures to eliminate it. Detecting individuals as well as organized criminal groups in illegally obtaining financial resources is not easy, but the cooperation of law enforcement authorities and mutual information is an opportunity to create such control mechanisms that would detect corruption and consistently punish corruption. Because corruption not only deprives us of significant funds, but we must realize that corruption undermines the foundations of democracy and the rule of law.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for debate on five motions for resolutions concerning Russia (2018/2754 (RSP))

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Madam President, today marks one month since Oleg Sentsov, a Ukrainian national and a filmmaker, and also a Russian political prisoner, began a hunger strike together with his fellow political prisoners Olexandr Kolchenko, Alexander Shumkov, and Volodymyr Balukh. These brave men are protesting against Russia’s persecution and arbitrary imprisonment of opposition voices, including especially those within annexed Crimea. They further demand the release of as many as 70 other Ukrainians and Crimean Tatars who have been arrested by Moscow on political grounds. Today is also the kick-off of the 2018 FIFA World Cup in Russia. The country will be in the global spotlight for the next month or so, but my Group today demands the immediate and unconditional release of Sentsov and his fellow prisoners, sentenced by a country that has no legitimate jurisdiction over them on political grounds. I also urge European political leaders to refrain from attending the 2018 World Cup in condemnation of Russia’s continued disrespecting of the multilateral, rules-based world order, be it in Crimea, eastern Ukraine, the European Union or US political processes – not to mention the poisoning, within my country, the United Kingdom, of its own citizens. I sincerely hope that the violations of human rights and international law that have become the norm for Moscow will not be lost from sight in the momentary cheering, comradeship and celebration that rightly accompanies every World Cup event.

name: Rebecca HARMS
text: Author. - Madam President, dear colleagues! Dear soccer fans, dear soccer players all over the world! We know that football is the most beautiful thing in the world. But there is a big and deep shadow on this soccer World Cup in Russia. When Oleh Sentsov, the filmmaker from the Ukrainian Crimea, went on hunger strike a month ago, he said: “If I die before or during the World Cup, there will be a resonance in favor of the other political prisoners of Vladimir Putin . ”Our resolution is an attempt to take Oleh Sentsov's desperation seriously and to support his demands. Hundreds of them are exiled in Russian prisons, penal and labor camps in today's Gulag archipelago. Minorities in Russia, the opposition are persecuted, suppressed and criminalized. In the four years since the Sochi Olympics ended, Vladimir Putin has done nothing to make the world more peaceful. He made her less peaceful. For politicians from the West, there can be no innocent visits, no innocent evenings with Vladimir Putin in the stadiums in Russia. It's sad, but that's the way it is. I don't understand what the excitement about meetings between German footballers and President Erdoğan is worth when Western politicians allow themselves to be exploited by Vladimir Putin's fame show in the next few days. The way of the politicians from the west should lead to Siberia, and they should visit Oleh Sentsov and others in these brutal penal colonies.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Madam President, it is about time that we in the EU and the international community raised our voice and supported economically and morally the courage of Russian human rights defenders who work tirelessly for democracy and justice in the shadow of Putin’s propaganda machine. Also now, during the World Cup, we will speak out loudly and show that we clearly condemn the state propaganda and repressive laws that undermine Russian civil society.  Human rights organisations are labelled as spies if they receive funding from abroad, and one person was convicted under the so-called gay propaganda law for sharing an article from ‘The Guardian’ on Facebook. These are two examples of the serious situation of human rights in Russia right now.  We must support, including financially, the democratic work in Russia. It is only through free and democratic societies that stand firm on the fulfilment of human rights that we will build long-term security in Europe and in the world.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: Author. - Madam President, we have become accustomed to freedom as well as to the fact that we no longer know the feeling of hunger. After seven decades in peacetime, we have become accustomed to the comfort of not thinking about our own freedom. The annexed and occupied Crimea peninsula, where the director of Ukrainian origin Oleh Sencov comes from, is a three-day drive from Strasbourg. Crimea is home to the Crimean Tatars, humble and brave people. The Crimean Tatars are a nation that respects values ​​and freedom. They are losing their freedom every day after Crimea was occupied by the Russian army in 2014. Today, Sencov sits behind bars in the far north of Russia, in the famous city of Salekhard camps and prisons. He was sentenced to 20 years in prison for alleged terrorism after protesting against the Russian occupation of Crimea. Salechard was one of the most famous symbols of the gulag before the war, under Josef Vissarionovič Stalin. It has remained so to this day and is proof that today's Kremlin is renewing the gulag over and over again. The dubious glory of the gulag continued after the war. In 1947, Stalin began building a railway in the Far North between the mouth of the Obu and the mouth of the Yenisei. This Salekhard gulag had the numbers 501 and 503. Thousands of people died here, the track was never completed. Even at the turn of the 2nd and 3rd millennium, Salekhard served the Kremlin. Hundreds of tortured Chechen freedom fighters disappeared in the Salekhard gulag in the early years of the 21st century. Today, no one knows how many Crimean Tatars have disappeared here. Sencov is on a hunger strike here for everyone who has done nothing wrong and yet been deprived of his liberty. For those who have been enslaved, abducted and tortured. Sencov and his fellow prisoners need our help. They need our attention. They need us to impose sanctions on the perpetrators of injustice, the representatives of the Russian Federation. Those who call for the lifting of sanctions against the Russian Federation are selling mine and your freedom, ladies and gentlemen. They sell a world where justice and respect for the law have a place. Help free Sencov and others! Let's stop the gulag.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Madam President, Oleg Sentsov, who spoke out against the illegal annexation of Crimea, was arrested and is serving a 20 year sentence in the gulag. Let’s not forget that this is the reality of Russia as people watch the World Cup. It is steps like these in which Putin’s regime reveals itself most clearly. Sentsov is one of 158 political prisoners, a number that has been rising sharply. Memorial, a Sakharov Prize—winning human rights organisation, has kept this list and now Oyub Titiev of Memorial in Chechnya was also arrested. This worrying trend of repression is underlined by the fact that Russia loses most cases before the European Court of Human Rights.  We call for the unconditional release of all political prisoners and human rights defenders and urge Russian authorities to respect people’s rights, including when they’re in detention. It means fair trials, an end to torture and confessions extracted under torture, access to lawyers and doctors, etcetera.  It is, first and foremost, in the interests of the Russian people that civil society organisations and media can do their work without intimidation and in freedom.

name: Róża THUN UND HOHENSTEIN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Madam President!Many monks set themselves on fire in protest against the Chinese occupation of Tibet, Piotr Szczęsny set himself on fire in the center of Warsaw in protest against the destruction of democracy by the current ruling party in Poland.People who understand the desperate political situation of their country sometimes do desperate acts to wake us up.Oleg Sentsov has been starving for a month in exile in faraway Yakutia, and Putin who sent him there (and many other political prisoners who dared to criticize the regime in Russia, the war in Ukraine and the occupation of Crimea), this Putin invites you today to the holidaysport.Let sport connect, but as long as Sentsov and those for whom he starves are not at large, I appeal: representatives of EU governments, watch this championship during the summit together with Donald Tusk in Brussels, but do not make the background for Putin's triumphant photos!Freedom for Sentsov!

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, it is a coincidence, or rather the force of destiny, that we are launching this important resolution on the very same day that Putin indulges in the international spotlight of the opening of the World Cup.  So let us remind him that spotlights cast dark shadows, and hidden in the deepest shadow of his ruthless regime we find dozens of innocent victims: Oleg Sentsov and many more; illegally detained, tortured, harassed and humiliated, Ukraine’s Tatars and other patriots whose only crime is to oppose the occupation of their homeland. So with today’s resolution we aim to fulfil our moral and political duty as European Democrats by trying to save Mr Sentsov’s life and help regain his freedom as well as that of all the other names in the resolution held in Russian captivity, deprived of freedom and human dignity, and even of legal and medical assistance. We must not cherish the illusion that we can halt Moscow’s illegal actions overnight, but today we can urge Putin to read this strong appeal by the European Parliament also as an opportunity, an undeserved chance to use the spotlight of the World Cup to improve his record by immediately releasing Mr Sentsov and all other political prisoners.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, four years after the illegal occupation of Crimea, we raise our voice in the European Parliament in solidarity with political prisoners of Russia – civilians who are persecuted because of their loyalty and love for this state and their homeland. That includes Oleg Sentsov, but also dozens of others, not to mention the long-standing imprisonment of Bekir Dehermendzhi. We raise our voices, because in this case the Geneva Convention on the persecution of civilian populations during war time has been brutally violated. We condemn, constantly, the illegal annexation of integral Ukrainian territories and we urge all politicians of the European Union to raise this issue with Russia while celebrating the World Cup. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: question "blue card".- I thank my colleague for accepting my question.He mentioned that it was necessary to start negotiations with Russia.Don't you think that the time has come for the High Representative of the European Union, Mrs Mogherini, to start a serious process with Russia to establish a system of negotiations between Ukraine and Russia regarding political prisoners?of Crimea held by Russia?

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: blue-card answer. – I did not say anything about us negotiating with Russia. I talked about raising a loud voice in defence of prisoners and I know that numerous European leaders have meetings with Vladimir Putin. I hope that this topic is also raised. Of course I share your view that Ms Mogherini should be very firm in putting this issue also in any encounters she may have with Russia.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, Oleg Sentsov will turn 42 next month. An active participant of the Maidan in Ukraine, there was no way he could stay silent once the ‘little green men’ appeared in his native Crimea. What price does Putin make people like Sentsov pay for defending his homeland’s freedom? 20 years imprisonment four thousand kilometres away from Moscow to the far north, where the temperature falls to -50 degrees, where the snow still stands in June, in a prison called ‘Polar Bear’ – what a symbolic name for the place where bears run freely and people normally do not live. Today, we all hope that Oleg will be strong enough to withstand the hunger strike. We all hope – and we demand – that his two children can see their father immediately, at home and in good health.
