Finally, I expect that those who will take part in World Cup matches in Moscow will not become a shameful part of Putin’s team.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, Oleg Sentsov’s case illuminates the terrible lawlessness and repressive measures and climate of impunity that permeates the illegally-occupied Crimea today, and we should not spare our words calling for the release of Oleg Sentsov and the other 158 Russian political prisoners. We cannot watch this idly, and we have to notice that today President Putin is celebrating the opening of the World Cup. And we have to remember what happened after the Sochi Olympics in 2014 – just some moments after these celebrations closing the Sochi Olympics, the illegal occupation of Crimea started. We have to now pay all of our attention to the people who are suffering in the prisons for politically-motivated charges, and I would like to particularly mention Oyub Titiev, the director of ‘Memorial’ in Chechnya.

name: Kazimierz Michał UJAZDOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman!I am an independent Member and speak as independent.I would like to sincerely thank my fellow Members for a very clear voice in defense of Mr. Sentsov and other political prisoners imprisoned in Russia and a voice against the systemic violation of human rights in Crimea.It is very good that this voice is so clear and unambiguous, and that so far we have not heard shameful voices in this debate, voices of support and support for Putin, because this has often happened at the seat of the European Parliament.The point is for us to be unambiguously and particularly consistent during the World Cup.We cannot allow Putin to use it, to take possession of football, so our voice should be much more consistent and stronger than before, which also means renewing our appeal and re-establishing a firm stance at the July session in Strasbourg.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: - Mr President, the World Cup is starting in Russia today and we will admire Potemkin's modern village in the form of polished football stadiums.But in their shadow are prisons with political prisoners, both own and foreign nationals, such as Oleg Sencov.Russia is an authoritarian regime in violation of international law.It is a regime to which fundamental rights say nothing.I am not just talking here about illegal arrests, but also torture.The list of those who are subject to intimidation, physical assault or false accusation just for trying to exercise their fundamental right to freedom of expression or assembly is long and growing.Russia is just as illegal and imperialist in occupying Crimea or parts of Georgia.It is our duty to save Oleg Sencov.That's why today we call him "Oleg, you will never walk alone" with the world of football.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: - Today the World Cup starts in Moscow with the opening match between the Russian and Saudi teams. Neither are football giants and the two countries are also lagging behind on The Economist's 'democracy index'. In the list of host cities for the World Cup I see resounding names: Moscow, St. Petersburg, Sochi, but no Labytnangi. And that's not surprising, because it's a small town just above the Arctic Circle. There, filmmaker Oleg Sentsov wages a lonely battle from his cell, a hunger strike that has now been going on for a month. With the last means that remains, he draws attention to all Ukrainian political prisoners in the country. He himself has been convicted for his criticism of the illegal annexation of Crimea, an outrageous propaganda stunt by Putin. Colleagues, within weeks the football circus will leave Russia and the country will return to the dark. I call on all European leaders to strongly condemn the imprisonment of Oleg Sentsov and all other Ukrainian political prisoners during this World Cup. Today I am already a supporter of Oleg Sentsov!

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, Oleg Sentsov opposed Russian annexation of Crimea. He was active in the Maidan revolution and helped deliver food to the Ukrainian servicemen blocked in their Crimean bases during the deadlock imposed by Russia.  Mr Sentsov is a man who exercised nothing more than his freedom of expression and his freedom of thought. That can send you all the way to jail in Russia. He was tried in a military court, and his trial had numerous grave procedural violations. He’s now serving his jail sentence in Labytnangi, that is to say 7 000 kilometres from here in the far north of Russia. For what? Well because he publicly opposed President Putin.  I urge the Russian Federation to do the only thing possible – to immediately release Mr Sentsov and to respect its international commitments. This should be done immediately.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I would like to stand up today to Mr Oleg Sencov, but also, of course, to others who are being unjustly imprisoned and their human rights being being violated.When else should we raise our voices than today, when the world championship begins in Russia.I think we should put just those other people in the glare of the spotlight, perhaps uncomfortable for Russia.Those facing arbitrary arrests whose fundamental human rights are being violated by the opposition.I think that today we really should raise our voices and put these people in the glare of those spotlights.While Mr Trump wants to invite Russia to the negotiating table, we should not, in my view, dodge.They should not dodge and be consistent, because Russia understands only the force of pressure.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, Crimea’s illegal annexation was a disaster for international law, and still this illegal occupation continues to undermine the pre-eminence of the rule of law and international relations.  The situation has concrete consequences on the lives of those who live in Crimea. Cultural heritage continues to be destroyed, and Crimea is set to lose invaluable historical sites. As a cultural activist, this perspective worries me. The destruction of cultural heritage is a form of ethno—genocide and a crime against humanity. I am extremely worried about the more urgent situation of Oleg Sentsov. As the days go by, his hunger strike becomes more and more alarming. I am increasingly worried, as are many. The European Union should do everything in its power to call for his immediate and unconditional release and provide for humanitarian assistance to him and all the other political prisoners held in custody in Russia and the occupied territories. Let my people go.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, one of the pillars for the survival of illegal regimes is their ability to control political opposition and civil society. In the case of putinism (I am sorry ... I came running ... trying to keep pace) that control goes beyond the borders of your country and living testimony of that are the 64 Ukrainian political prisoners who, in Russian jails and in the occupied territories of Crimea , they pay dearly for the price of their courage. Among them is Oleg Sentsov, the Ukrainian filmmaker illegally sentenced to 20 years in prison in Russia for alleged terrorist activities in Crimea, whose health is starting to deteriorate worryingly after starting a hunger strike exactly one month ago to demand immediate release of his countrymen. Dear Colleagues, on the day when the world football championship in Russia also begins - an event that Mr Putin has used as a propaganda tool to project his power - the European Union must, once again, affirm that human rights are an essential component of its foreign policy and therefore demand the immediate release of Ukrainian citizens illegally detained in Russia in undignified and inhumane conditions.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the illegal annexation of the Crimean peninsula by Russia has entailed a marked deterioration of the human rights situation on the peninsula and the jailing of people whose sole crime is to reject the illegal annexation. Oleg Sentsov is one of them.  Shortly after the illegal annexation, Oleg Sentsov was arrested in Crimea. After a trial which lacked all guarantees of fairness, and in which he was judged as a Russian citizen and denied the consular assistance of the Ukranian authorities despite clearly be in Ukrainian, Mr Sentsov was sentenced to 20 years in prison, accused of plotting terrorist acts for which the investigators could not find any evidence. As many Members have highlighted, he has been serving this prison sentence in remote regions of the Russian Federation, currently in Russia’s northernmost prison on the Yamal peninsula, often in solitary confinement. Exactly one month ago, he started a hunger strike to protest at the incarceration of all his fellow Ukranian political prisoners in Russia and demand their release. Oleg Sentsov’s case is no longer just a judicial or political one. It is now a matter of human compassion. His health is at risk of rapid deterioration. He should be immediately and unconditionally released on humanitarian grounds. The European Union has closely followed the situation of Mr Sentsov and fellow Ukranian prisoners. It has regularly urged Russia to release all of them, both those who are in Russia and those on the Crimean peninsula. Diplomats from the European Union delegation and Member States’ embassies in Moscow have been present at court hearings related to these cases and are in contact with the lawyers. In addition to the case of Mr Sentsov, we have often raised other cases – such as those of Olexandr Kolchenko, Stanislas Klykh and Mykola Karpyuk – in bilateral meetings with Russian representatives as well as in public statements, including in international forums such as the Council of Europe and the Organisation for Security and Cooperation of Europe.  We are also following with concern the case of Ukranian journalist Roman Sushchenko who was sentenced on 4 June in Moscow to 12 years in prison for alleged acts of espionage in what appears to be another attack on the freedom of the press. Our statement on 25 May, focusing on Oleg Sentsov, Volodymyr Balukh, Server Mustafayev and Edem Smailov, reiterated that the European Union expects international human rights standards to be upheld on the Crimean peninsula and that all illegally detained Ukrainian citizens, in Russia and on the Crimean peninsula, should be released without delay. I would also like to recall President Tusk’s call to the G7 leaders last week to show their support for and solidarity with Oleg Sentsov. This is a message that we will continue to repeat to the Russian authorities. Lastly, let me restate that the European Union remains committed to implementing in full its policy of non-recognition of the illegal annexation of Crimea and Sevastopol and we fully support the sovereignty, independence and territorial integrity of Ukraine.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Commissioner!As you can see, there is perhaps a high degree of agreement between Parliament and the Commission.I close the debate.The vote will take place after the debates end at12.00.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on the human rights situation in Bahrain, in particular the situation of Nabil Rajab (2018/2755 (RSP)).

name: David CAMPBELL BANNERMAN
text: author. – Mr President, here we go again: yet another motion attacking Bahrain – probably influenced by Iran, who claim Bahrain as their own and are intent on destabilising the whole Middle East. Bahrain is a key ally of EU Member States. Our friendship is of vital importance in political and economic relations, energy and security. Bahrain is also of strategic interest to NATO, and the UK has opened a military base there staffed by 500 military personnel. Whilst we should have an open and frank dialogue with our Bahraini friends on human rights, welcome reforms are taking place now. Over 8 000 police officers have received human rights training and also 100 members of the judiciary. Furthermore, the independent Special Investigations Unit, which I have visited, now vigorously investigates any allegation of mistreatment, and this is the first of its kind in the Middle East. On the matter of Mr Nabeel Rajab: he was found guilty of spreading false information designed to undermine national security, and he does continue to be afforded his full legal rights. It would be better to focus on extreme states such as Iran and the worst execution rate in the world.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. - Mister President! Last week's five-year prison sentence against human rights activist Nabil Rajab in Bahrain speaks for itself. Those responsible in Bahrain are unwilling to respect fundamental freedoms. Therefore, in our resolution, we call for the unconditional release of Nabil Rajab and all other prisoners of conscience. We call on the representatives of the European External Action Service, the European Council and the Member States to regularly raise awareness of human rights violations in Bahrain. The implementation of targeted punitive measures against those responsible must also be considered. And it is unacceptable that European companies should continue to supply surveillance technology to the Bahraini government and thereby contribute to the repression of civil society actors. All EU member states have to guarantee strict compliance with export restrictions on weapons and surveillance technology. And I would ask the previous speaker, Mr Bannerman, to check where he got his information. Our information did not come from Iran, but from really reliable sources.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, it is time for the Government of Bahrain to free Nabeel Rajab.  He is in prison right now simply for standing up for human rights. Nabeel Rajab is one of many human rights defenders, political activists, opposition leaders and journalists that the authorities have unjustly imprisoned in the past years as the human rights situation has got increasingly worse, including for female human rights defenders. It is time for the EU to act and react.  I am also very concerned by the dramatic increase in the use of the death penalty and the new laws allowing civilians to be tried in military courts. We call on Bahrain immediately and unconditionally to release Nabeel Rajab, as well as Abdulhadi al-Khawaja and all imprisoned human rights defenders, and stop the use of the death penalty.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: author. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the unstoppable repression underway in Bahrain gags the whole of civil society, eliminating any form of opposition possible. The arrogance of this government is such that, twice, it has refused to receive a delegation from the Subcommittee on Human Rights of this Parliament, the second time even withdrawing a previous formal invitation. This is clear demonstration of Bahrain's attitude towards human rights and towards those who dare to even mention them. The recent confirmation of Nabeel Rajab's conviction on appeal is just one of the many proofs of the ferocious persistence of power against any form of dissidence, freedom of thought and information. Nabeel Rajab, a free and courageous man, stripped of all rights, left in inhumane conditions of detention and in poor health, is the symbol of the struggle against this repression. If we fail to defend the symbol of this struggle, if we leave only one man who embodies the principles we vouch for in that country, it will be human rights themselves that have failed in Bahrain. Nabeel Rajab must be released immediately and unconditionally.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: Author. - Mr President, let me also express my views on the resolution concerning Nabil Rajab. The PPE and ECR resolutions are a resolution that really reflects this case and other cases where people in Bahrain are imprisoned for their political views and their actions. In this sense, the EU, through this resolution, expresses its views and concerns about this case, which has a much wider scope. More than 13 activists have been arrested in Bahrain since 2011, all of which were relatively unclear. Unfortunately, human rights and freedoms are being curtailed, which is contrary to our European values. The right to a fair trial, the right of access to a court of law, the right to a fair trial and other rights must always be respected. Human rights activists and fighters are an important component of any democracy and it is essential that they have a place in democracy. That is why it does not end with this resolution. We want an open dialogue with Bahrain, and we hope that we will succeed.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr President, this is a 'blue card' for you, because our political group has two minutes for Mr Zdechovský.So please check with your secretariat, as we don't want to be penalized.I speak here as a PPE coordinator.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: We check it and I can show you the printout I'm using - here is one minute.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: author. - Mr President, once again we are discussing Bahrain. Since 2011 and the crushing of popular protests with the help of the Saudi and Emirati armies, the country has been steeped in repression and a growing denial of human rights. The first victims are human rights defenders, often arrested and sentenced on the basis of confessions obtained under torture. Many are banned from traveling, there are numerous disqualifications and more and more civil trials are being brought before military courts. The UN and the big NGOs also denounce the harassment of the Shiite population, which constitutes, let us remember, the majority of the population. Accused - of course, as others here accuse us - of playing into the hands of the big Iranian neighbor. The fight against terrorism is on the safe side and the National Security Agency has almost a free hand to carry out arrests and interrogations in this context. After a 7-year moratorium, executions have effectively resumed and death sentences are increasing. Nabil Rajab has become a symbol of this struggle for human rights. He was due for release this month after serving a new 2-year sentence in appalling prison conditions, but has just been sentenced to an additional 5 years in prison. Commissioner, I would like to speak here for Adam, his 21-year-old son, who is concerned about his father's deteriorating health and would like one of our ambassadors to visit him. I ask you to make yourself the spokesperson for this request. The dano-Bahraini citizen Abdulhadi al-Khawaja has also been detained since April 2011, sentenced to life imprisonment for peaceful activities, or the blogger Abduljalil al-Singace, and there are many others. All of this in itself would bode badly for the upcoming elections slated for next October, when the two main opposition parties have been dissolved, Al Wefaq, the main Shiite party, and Waad, the secular party. But their members have even just been banned from running for office, like any citizen convicted of crimes. How can you have trade relations and sell weapons and surveillance equipment to a country like this?

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Mr President, with any human rights resolution we seek to speak with one voice, as representatives of the European people and of different political parties. This strong, united message shows that our support for human rights binds us, no matter where in the world those rights are violated and no matter the other differences of opinion and political colour between us here in the Parliament. In negotiations we seek compromise to ensure broad support. How tragic is it then that, after we had successfully negotiated a text taking on board all views, the EPP and the ECR decided to propose an alternative resolution. Not only is it a clear breach of trust, it also shows division on the importance of human rights in Bahrain. Our group is clear: it believes human rights should be addressed, no matter the political relations, trade interests and security or other shared areas of cooperation, because respect for universal human rights needs defending and, if the EU or this Parliament together do not defend them, who will? I have a question for my colleague, Mr Campbell Bannerman. Following your logic, are you suggesting that the spreading of false information on Brexit should have led to prison sentences?

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group.- Mr President, we have tried to have a dialogue ... (the President cut off the speaker).

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Excuse me, I will explain this two-minute case to clarify the situation. It was the following: Tomáš should get one minute as author. You asked for one minute and, instead of adding it together to make two minutes, the note was one minute. It was a kind of misinformation. So please accept it as an explanation. The floor is yours on behalf of your political group.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, unbelievable these Socialists! Mr. President, we have always tried to have a dialogue with Bahrain on the issue of rights. Unfortunately, this dialogue is not possible given the refusal of the authorities, on two occasions, to receive a delegation from the European Parliament. This request for dialogue is an initiative of the EPP, Mrs Schaake. This visit would have been an opportunity to discuss openly the challenges that the country must meet in terms of respect for rights, I am thinking in particular of respect for freedom of expression, whether for human rights defenders or for participation. opposition parties to the political game, particularly in the context of the elections scheduled for this fall. The case of Nabil Rajab, which the European Parliament has already raised on several occasions, is very worrying and we await a strong signal from the country's authorities, namely his immediate release. Mr President, I hope that next time, under your presidency, the EPP will not be penalized for the mismanagement of speaking time.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: Neither the EPP nor any political group will ever suffer, but once again please note that there was an urgent response from the secretariat, the circumstances under which this happened were immediately explained.And my first reaction was of course also to extend the time.So please accept this and let us consider that we have a closed case.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the cases of Nabeel Rajab Abdulhadi al-Khawaja and many others demonstrate Bahrain’s complete disregard for freedom of expression.  I am also very concerned by the situation of Syed Ahmed al-Badawi, whose family has been judicially harassed and detained with allegations of torture, simply because of his peaceful human rights activities. The Bahraini government’s attacks on democracy become more serious every day. Ahead of elections set to take place in the autumn, the authorities have passed a bill banning members of dissolved opposition groups from running for elections – depriving more than one hundred people of their citizenship, and increased their use of the death penalty. I’m horrified by the state of affairs in Bahrain, particularly in light of the involvement of several European governments, including my own. The British Government’s complicity in grave and systematic human rights violations in Bahrain is unacceptable and needs to be called out. I call on the Bahraini authorities to immediately and unconditionally release Nabeel and all political prisoners.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, even before our joint, or rather partially common resolution was publicly available, the Bahraini ambassador, by contacting the parliamentarians, made a sensational case of what my Latin ancestors they called excusatio non petita, accusatio manifesta. According to the documents sent to us, in fact, in the country there would be nothing more than a lively climate of political and cultural debate, an independent and transparent judicial system and adequate human rights protection mechanisms, and Nabeel Rajab would be fine and rightly undergoing a trial , obviously a process with all the necessary guarantees. An interesting picture, too bad it does not correspond to reality, dear colleagues, a reality that is quite different and is constantly worsening. The al-Wefaq and Waad opposition groups have been dissolved and their members will be barred from participating in the elections. Human rights defenders have been arrested, tortured and their citizenship stripped, and independent newspapers are closed. Nabeel Rajab has lost his lawsuit appeal and will go to jail for tweets. You have understood correctly, colleagues, for tweets in 2018. I am saddened to see that some groups in Parliament seem to share more the views of the Bahraini authorities and have presented an alternative resolution that is much softer than it should. Colleagues, words are no longer enough, today we need facts. Member States must suspend export licenses for surveillance equipment, weapons and any devices the government may use for repression. If we truly believe in all those values ​​that we often talk about in this House, now is the time to prove it. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Dear colleague, Italy is one of the largest exporters of surveillance equipment to Bahrain.You are currently in government.Can you tell us what specific steps you have already taken for Italy to stop exporting these surveillance devices to Bahrain?Thank you for your specific answer.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: answer to a "blue card" question.- Dear colleague, consistently with what has been done over the years, we will also give the same message to our government.I would like to point out that the undersecretaries of the current executive were appointed the day before yesterday.So this government is now taking over and it will obviously be our duty and our will to carry this message and therefore expect our country to lead by example.But let us hope that the same will come from all the other 27 Member States, because otherwise, if only one does it and the others turn away, we are making fun of ourselves, as is often the case in this House.

name: Jacques COLOMBIER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, the case of Nabil Rajab in Bahrain naturally challenges us and worries us. If we support minorities who are victims of discrimination and abuse, we think first and foremost, in the Middle East, of the Christian populations, whose Islamist project aims to eradicate the presence, much earlier than that of Islam. There is little awareness here against this major tragedy. In Bahrain, it is not a minority, but the majority of the Shiite population who are discriminated against by a Sunni emirate. The European Union, which supports such unsavory countries as Qatar or Saudi Arabia, which mistreats its Shiite minority, is ill-placed - I think it is - to intervene on this issue, as on many others. It is by taking a balanced position, without choosing Riyadh over Tehran or even vice versa, that European countries could play a mediating role. But it is above all by resuming each of their diplomatic sovereignty that the European nations will regain a policy in accordance with their interests. They could therefore intervene in a much more credible manner in questions such as those mentioned here.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: - Mr President, today we want to support Bahraini human rights defender Bahrain Rajab, mainly because we believe that freedom of speech is a fundamental human right and that its application contributes to the good functioning of society.Today, Nabal Rajab faces a total of 7 years in prison for expressing his opinion on Twitter about, among other things, the bombing of Yemen by Saudi Arabia, and thus under the Bahraini law was to commit the crime of insulting a neighboring state.The trial of Mr Rajab has been conducted several times in a manner contrary to Bahraini law.However, there is a chance that Mr Rajab will be pardoned.We now call on Bahrain not to subject Mr Rajab to any degrading treatment, torture or to ensure that his trial meets the international standards of a fair trial.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, the Bahraini Government has been trying its best to paint a picture of the country in which there is respect for fundamental values and human rights, but no amount of PR effort can gloss over the human rights violations and the repression, which continue to increase. This is the fourth consecutive year in which this House has adopted a resolution on Bahrain calling for the release of those who are detained simply because they exercise their freedom of expression, including Nabeel Rajab and Abdulhadi al-Khawaja and many, many others. It is time we put Bahrain on notice that failure to respect fundamental rights will be met with consequences. As for those on the other side of the House who are trying to water down the resolution, I ask you to consider: history has shown that appeasement does not work with an authoritarian regime. My questions to the Commissioner are: will the EU consider imposing targeted measures against those responsible for human rights violations, and when will the Member States, including the UK, halt transfers of weapons, surveillance and intelligence equipment that can be used by Bahrain in this unacceptable crackdown … (The President cut off the speaker)

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, at this very moment, just a few months before the legislative elections, the National Assembly of Bahrain is in the process of passing a law whose practical effect will be to ban and silence opposition to the current government forever. Dear Colleagues, the truth is that, since June 2016, the Bahrain regime has radically toughened repression against dissent and human rights activists, multiplying arbitrary arrests, tortures and civil trials by military courts and passing laws that threaten severely limit the political rights of its citizens. This repression has again hit Nabeel Rajab, blogger and president of the Bahrain Human Rights Center, who, detained for the sixth time since 2011, has now seen his five-year prison sentence imposed last February ratified. What the regime criminalizes is called, in the European Union, free exercise of the right to freedom of expression. Bahrain must respect the commitments made with the ratification of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights and immediately unconditionally release a citizen who simply intends to exercise his freedom of speech, courageously and peacefully.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, human rights abuses in Bahrain are on the agenda. It has been known since 2011 that the authorities oppress too many activists. The right to a fair trial and the right of lawyers to access defendants have been effectively abolished, while there is a complete suppression of human rights. The fact that arms are being sold from the West to Bahrain, as well as the fact that there are growing commercial interests, should not lead our Parliament to turn a blind eye to human rights abuses in Bahrain. In this case, there must be an immediate release of Nabeel Rajab, who denounced the Coalition of Saudi Arabia, which has been constantly bombing Yemen and causing hundreds of casualties. Nabeel Rajab has been convicted and is in jail. We demand his immediate release!

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Mr Chairman! Despite the fundamentally sound intentions of defending human rights in Bahrain, I think you are doing it wrong. First of all, yesterday you admonished Poland for exerting political pressure on the courts, and now you are doing the same, only in relation to a foreign country. You are trying to put political pressure on the trial in Bahrain. The only thing that can be called for is for the king to exercise his right of grace, not to put pressure on the courts. Secondly, it is a gross inconsistency, because in Great Britain we tolerate the fact that a man - Tommy Robinson - is unjustifiably detained, that the court forbids information about his trial, precisely in the name of not exerting political pressure on him, but we do not react to it at home, and we teach other countries. And third, writing such declarations does nothing. As you rightly said, you are writing this for the fourth year in a row, so it's time to draw conclusions. That's not how things like that are handled. Ask Trump, he can handle such things. Let him go there and arrange something.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, and good morning, Commissioner Arias Cañete. We were together from 6 o’clock yesterday evening until 4 o’clock this morning as we were finalising the renewable energy file, and it is good to see you back here. We must both be running on renewable energy. Maidir leis an gcás seo, ba mhaith liom a rá ar dtús, mar a dúirt an Feisire Campbell Bannerman, tá gaol cairdiúil againn leis an tír seo, Bairéin, agus caithfimid aitheantas a thabhairt don dul chun cinn atá déanta maidir leis na saoránaigh i gcoitinne chun a saol a fheabhsú. Ach ag an am céanna, ní hé sin le rá gur cheart dúinn súil dhall a thabhairt ar na droch-rudaí atá ag tarlu sa tír, go háirithe mar a bhaineann le Nabeel Rajab. Chaith sé bliain i bpríosún ag fanacht lena thriail a cuireadh ar ceall fiche uair. Deirtear anois go bhfuil sé ina chillín ar feadh trí uair an chloig is fiche gach uile lá. Níl sé seo féaráilte in aon chor agus is ceart dúinn é sin a thaispeáint dóibh agus gach iarracht a dhéanamh chun é a ligean saor.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, as you will know, the European Union has followed developments in Bahrain for many years now. While in the past we have been encouraged by progress made, recently our worries have increased with the shrinking of political space in the country. As a result, we have sought to engage Bahrain in a comprehensive dialogue on human rights. This is why we are working hard to establish an informal human rights dialogue, with the third meeting taking place on 15 May in Manama. We have strongly supported the request of the European Parliament’s Subcommittee on Human Rights to visit Bahrain, and we hope that the authorities will soon give their agreement to permit the visit to go ahead. 2018 is a particularly important year because of the upcoming parliamentary elections this autumn, but unfortunately the adoption on 11 June of an amendment to the electoral law, which bans opposition members from running in elections, is not a step in the right direction. Freedom of expression and association, the right to a fair trial and respect for human rights defenders are among the points which we stress in our contact with Bahrain.  The specific case of Nabeel Rajab has become symbolic of the difficulties being experienced by human rights defenders and by whoever expresses political dissent in Bahrain. This is a case on which the High Representative / Vice—President has repeatedly spoken publicly, including very recently, on 6 June, in reaction to the news that the Bahrain Court of Appeal had upheld a five-year prison sentence against Mr Rajab for comments posted on social media. We call on Bahrain to grant Mr Rajab’s release, including on humanitarian grounds, given the reported deterioration of his health. The European Union will continue to use all available means to further address the human rights situation in Bahrain and hopes that Bahrain will find again the path of dialogue and reconciliation, which it had started to follow so well at the end of 2011 in line with the recommendations of the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry. The European Union remains supportive of Bahrain’s long—term stability and is convinced that it can only be sustained if peaceful political grievances can be expressed freely. We have consistently encouraged all parties to move forward with democratic reforms in a peaceful and constructive manner. Finally, regarding Ms Gill’s question, I would like to say that targeted measures are an essential tool of the European Union’s common foreign and security policy and are used by the European Union as part of an integrated and comprehensive policy approach involving political dialogue, complementary efforts and the use of other instruments at its disposal. The European Union continues to have dialogue with the Bahraini authorities in a frank manner, including on human rights. The European Union will continue to closely follow the human rights situation on the ground, and on that basis, it will decide on possible measures.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place after the debates end at12.00.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: The next item is the debate on six motions for resolutions on the situation of refugees belonging to the Rohingya minority, in particular the plight of children (2018/2756 (RSP).

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: Author. - Mister President! In February, we MEPs in the Cox’s Bazar refugee camp gained a realistic impression of the efforts of international aid organizations to provide the Rohingya refugees or displaced persons with essentials. It quickly became clear to us that the demand was significantly higher. The situation is particularly difficult for children, as there is a lack of access to adequate psychological and medical care, as well as access to education and protection from exploitation. The international community urgently needs to make funds available for humanitarian aid, especially in view of the approaching monsoons. The Rohingya live in this dire situation because they have been displaced by extreme violence. The impunity of those responsible must come to an end, also in order to make a return of the Rohingya to Myanmar possible again in the long term. The EU and its member states should actively support processes to deal with crimes in Myanmar - for example through the International Criminal Court. An international, impartial and independent mechanism at the UN level should be established to collect and analyze evidence of serious crimes in the Rakhine State. In this context, the government in Myanmar must finally grant access to independent observers, especially the UN fact-finding mission, to investigate allegations of serious human rights violations.

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: author. – Mr President and fellow MEPs, I want to tell a story and make a plea. I was in Bangladesh in September and witnessed at the border burning villages in neighbouring Myanmar. I heard harrowing stories of murder and rape, ethnic cleansing and genocide. I was fortunate to return to Bangladesh just a couple of weeks ago, accompanied by two amazing businessman, Aneel Mussarat and Iqbal Ahmed. We took across six trucks of food and medicine and distributed 33 000 family packs of food and medicine. But I’m sad to say that I am ashamed to look these two gentlemen in the eye and look in the eye of the refugees, because in spite of passing three resolutions and in spite of the fact that we are about to pass a fourth, nothing has been achieved. I’m sad to say that we now need to implement these resolutions. We need to get these refugees returned voluntarily to their ancestral homes in safety and dignity guaranteed by the UN in white helmets. We need independent investigation of crimes against humanity and the perpetrators brought to justice. We need restoration of citizenship and equal rights to the Rohingyas back in Myanmar. Until that is achieved, we’ve achieved nothing.

name: Soraya POST
text: author. – Mr President, I have seen the devastating situation in Cox’s Baazar, the world’s largest refugee camp, where 1.2 million Rohingya refugees are seeking protection from ethnic cleansing in Myanmar. The majority are women who have fled along with their children, many being victims of violence and sexual assaults. Not only do these children lack food, clean water, health care, trauma therapy, education and security, but they are also victims of trafficking, violence, sexual exploitation and child marriage. During the monsoon season, they will also be at high risk of deadly disease outbreaks and landslides. The international community has to place the personal safety of every individual on the top of their security agendas. To keep these women and children safe, and to put pressure on Myanmar to end the persecution of the Rohingya, there is a need for an independent investigation.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Author. - Mister President! Unfortunately, what we feared has happened. The situation of the Rohingya, who had to flee from their homeland to Bangladesh a year ago before the violent riots by the military and the police in Myanmar, has not changed. So far, no one has been able to return to their homeland, despite the agreements already concluded between Myanmar and Bangladesh with the assistance of the United Nations. On the contrary: the situation in the world's largest refugee camp has worsened with the onset of the monsoons. The first fatalities are already to be mourned in Bangladesh. People have also died in the Rohingya refugee camps. Landslides have destroyed the already few sanitary facilities and the drinking water supply, and the meager dwellings have been washed down the hills. The outbreak of epidemics threatens. The worst hit again is the weakest: the children who have now been virtually without schooling for a year and are threatened by abuse and human trafficking. The international community must deliver on its aid pledges for the refugees. At the same time, however, the pressure on the military rulers in Myanmar in particular must be increased, including through sanctions against some of their representatives, so that they declare their willingness to resolve the conflict. China, which has great influence over the military in Myanmar, should be acted upon to help solve the problem. The situation has been exacerbated by the fact that civil war has broken out again in Shan and Kachin states in Myanmar. There, too, people had to leave their villages again, thousands were displaced, and several hundred have already died. Myanmar remains a problem case and we should keep it under surveillance.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. - Mr President, the Rohingya are one of the most persecuted minorities and until recently one of the most forgotten. It has been a genocide that has put them back on the map. We have all heard the figures: 900,000 people - of whom more than 500,000 were boys and girls - fled torture, arbitrary detentions, the burning of entire villages. We know that the Myanmar army raped women as part of the expulsion strategy and that, nine months later, 48,000 of these women are waiting to give birth in Bangladesh in totally unsanitary conditions. The United Nations and Myanmar signed another memorandum for the voluntary return of the Rohingya under certain conditions: the recognition of citizenship and an end to violence. Unfortunately, there is still a long way to go for these conditions to be met, because the expulsion of the Rohingya from their territory not only responds to a religious or ethnic conflict, but, above all, to big business that nobody talks about. It is the army that has control over the management of the land and is, at the same time, responsible for the Rohingya genocide and their displacement. The Land Law and the Foreign Investment Law are allowing the massive entry of transnational capital, promoting extractivism, agribusiness and water grabbing precisely in Rohingya territory. Between 2010 and 2013, more than one million hectares inhabited by the Rohingya were granted to agro-industrial projects of multinationals. In the lands from which they were displaced, over their burned houses, military bases are now being built to control the territory. The international community must ensure that its investments never cover human rights violations or serve to strengthen a system that systematically discriminates against the Rohingya population and further reduces the chances of return. Because, if we do not take forceful measures to ensure the end of violence, access to justice and return and measures of non-repetition, we will be indirect accomplices of these crimes against humanity. It's time to act.

name: Urmas PAET
text: author. – Mr President, there are more than 720 000 Rohingya children in Bangladesh and Myanmar in dire need of assistance and protection. More than 43 000 of them have lost at least one, if not two, parents. All of them have witnessed atrocities, and many of them are suffering from malnutrition, physical abuse and illnesses. Rape is used as a tool by Myanmar soldiers in their campaign of ethnic cleansing.  Rohingya women and children are extremely exposed to the risk of being trafficked into prostitution and to the risk of sexual harassment, and the situation of the Rohingyas is already getting worse due to the monsoon. The international community must do its utmost to find a sustainable approach to the tragic situation, but the Myanmar authorities should bear in mind that ethnic cleansing does not go without punishment.  The European Union should seek accountability for those responsible in Myanmar and work towards referring the situation in Myanmar to the International Criminal Court.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. President, this is the fourth Resolution that we present here on the dramatic situation of the Rohingya and, I hope it is the last!, Although I am afraid it will not be because the violation of the human rights of the most persecuted minority in the world does not ceases. The aim is to carry out an ethnic cleansing through killings and displacement of those who receive the hatred of a good part of the population of Myanmar, supported by the military and a government that turns its back on the Rohingya people. 900,000 innocents, of whom more than half a million are children, have had to flee to Bangladesh for their lives. Sexual violence and rape are used against women and girls as a weapon of war. Girls and women are trafficked into refugee camps, where they have to prostitute themselves. The situation of children is dramatic, and I hope that the agreement between the United Nations and Myanmar will be fulfilled and that the government will allow the return of the displaced in safety. The European Union must play a predominant role in the investigation and prosecution of crimes against humanity committed against this defenseless people.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, tomorrow is the festival of Eid, a time to feast and celebrate with family and friends. Sadly, this will be an Eid to forget for Myanmar’s Rohingya community. Rohingyas are going from crisis to crisis. The next four months threaten catastrophic risk for the refugees, especially children. Now heavy rains mark the start of the monsoon season, which is predicted to bring with it disease, landslides, flash flooding and death.  There is a dire need to step up the international support during this critical time, to address the humanitarian needs of both the refugees and the whole community. Sadly, only one fifth of the UN Joint Response Plan’s appeal for funding has been met. We need a comprehensive and sustainable approach to this humanitarian crisis because there is no realistic prospect of safe and voluntary return. Furthermore, we also cannot forget the root cause of this tragedy. I urge the Vice-President / High Representative to lead the call for justice and explore all avenues to hold perpetrators to account, whilst ensuring that evidence of atrocities is collected and preserved for future legal proceedings. But the monsoon season is now, so saving lives must be our priority.

name: Jadwiga WIŚNIEWSKA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen! The Rohingya people are one of the most persecuted minorities in the world. The violence perpetrated by the Burmese military is a classic example of ethnic cleansing: murder, burning villages, mass rape. Although the Rohingya have lived in Burma for generations, they are considered intruders who are denied citizenship, access to health and education. For the sake of their health, they mainly flee to Bangladesh. According to UNICEF, 693,000 fled from August 2017 to April this year. people, more than half of which are children. And in 2018, 48 thousand. women and girls in refugee camps will give birth to children, mainly those conceived as a result of rape by the Burmese army. Due to limited access to medical care, many of them will die soon after giving birth. Those children who do survive will be at risk of malnutrition, violence, sexual abuse or will become victims of human traffickers. This nightmare must be stopped and all incitement to hatred must be clearly condemned. Humanitarian aid is necessary and I am calling for such help.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group.- (NL) Mr President, Commissioner, 48 000 babies, that is the number that aid organizations estimate of the number of babies that will be born in the coming days and weeks in the camps.Babies conceived with hatred and violence, not love.Mothers who already live in very dire circumstances, often with children who are not educated and who are malnourished.Colleagues, I would like to draw special attention here to the fate of the mothers and the children.How do you want a mom to love a child born after a brutal rape?We must assist those parents.We have to assist those mommies.We have to take care of those children.And that is the job of Europe.Life in those camps is miserable.And today Europe must give a signal, we must punish perpetrators.But we must above all focus on counseling the mothers who are about to give birth, so that those children at least get fair opportunities in those camps.We are obliged to.Thank you.

name: Seán KELLY
text: - A Uachtaráin, pléimid a lán cásanna truamhéalacha sa Pharlaimint seo agus is dóigh liom gurb é seo an cás is truamhéalaí ar fad mar nílimid ag caint faoi dhuine aonaránach. Táimid ag caint faoi suas le milliún duine nach bhfuil aon chearta acu i ndáiríre. Tá saol i bhfad níos fearr ag na hainmhithe fiáine trasna an domhain ná mar atá ag muintir Rohingya. Tá siad i mbaol gach saghas fogha - fogha gnéasach, fogha fisiciúil - tá siad i gcampaí na dteifeach agus i mbaol ocrais, i mbaol galar, agus i mbaol báis. Agus níl a dhóthain airde á tabhairt orthu. Agus mar a dúirt mo chara, Zeller, caithfimid comhoibriú, go háirithe leis an tSín agus na Náisiúin Aontaithe, chun cabhrú leo. Agus go háirithe, is truamhéalach ar fad go bhfuil an méid sin leanaí agus gan a ndóthain le n-ithe acu, nach bhfuil seans acu oideachas a fháil agus nach bhfuil aon todhchaí ann i ndáiríre dóibh. Mura dtógaimid ceannaireacht ar an scéal seo, mura gcuirimid brú ar an tSín, agus mura gcomhoibrímid leis na Náisiúin Aontaithe chun an scéal seo a fheabhsú agus a cheartú go luath, leanfaidh sé ar aghaidh duus e nine.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the situation of the Rohingya in Myanmar represents one of the worst humanitarian crises we are witnessing today. Once again, children are among the most affected by what has been called, on several occasions, a real ethnic cleansing. According to UNICEF, 534,000 Rohingya children were refugees in Bangladesh last year, in disastrous sanitation conditions, exposed to the risk of violence, exploitation and abuse of all kinds. Many Rohingya children born in Myanmar have never received any birth certificates, in complete contradiction with the UN Convention on the Rights of the Child to which Myanmar is also a signatory. A denial of civil rights for these children that begins from birth, with very serious consequences, such as the inability to obtain identity documents and to have access to health care or education, children who, in a word, we can define ghost children. The Union must intervene in the competent fora, with a firm voice to guarantee the Rohingya full respect for their fundamental and civil rights, with particular attention to children.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: – Mr President, honourable Commissioner, our international community’s response, I am afraid, can at the very best be described as lacking. Identification of the Rohingya as Rohingya itself has been shied away from. Citizenship has not been addressed adequately at all. Meanwhile the military’s ethnic cleansing of the Muslim and non-Buddhists continues, the aim ultimately being to create a Buddhist state. Without citizenship being addressed, ultimately that ethnic cleansing will succeed, and without consequences there are no costs to Myanmar for that ethnic cleansing. Honourable Commissioner, if this House was to put a question to you and ask, what would your response be if we asked that trade measures to include investigative mechanism under the ‘Everything but Arms’ principles should now be invoked? Is it not time that we made consequences to all of the words that we have spoken on this issue over many years?

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: – Mr President, the Rohingya are being persecuted and are suffering a severe humanitarian crisis, and children are the most vulnerable. UNICEF states that 720 000 Rohingya children need assistance and protection now. That is 720 000 children being denied a chance for a future: being subject to rape, violence and trauma, being orphaned, being trafficked, being hungry, being denied an education, being forced to give birth to their rapists’ children, and without proper healthcare. These are children who have been suffering far too long and enduring beyond what anyone should have to endure in a lifetime. No child deserves this. It is the duty of the Myanmar Government and that of Bangladesh to do everything they can to safeguard the rights of all children affected by the crisis and to guarantee their safety. The EU must continue working to stop the crisis and it must look into other measures if Myanmar refuses to uphold the rights of the Rohingya.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: – Mr President, it is important that we do not close our eyes to the situation of the Rohingya refugees. We know that our voice is heard, and today’s resolution should contribute to improving the situation of the most vulnerable, the children. We should also be grateful to Bangladesh for its support for the refugees. Europe has an obligation substantially to increase its financial contributions for humanitarian aid and lifesaving support. We should also be concerned about the political stability of the country. The situation is tense and elections are scheduled for the end of the year. It is important that they will be fair and transparent. Human rights violations, enforced disappearances and riots are happening on a daily basis, and the leader of the opposition, Khaleda Zia, is in prison under questionable conditions. It is in our interest that the forthcoming elections meet democratic standards and guarantee stability in this country.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: - Mr President, a lot has already been said this morning about the tragedy of the Rohingyas and their forced exile in Bangladesh: 900,000 refugees, including more than half a million children, who live, who survive - who do not survive in fact - in Cox's Bazar camp, in appalling living conditions; 50,000 babies are expected to be born in these makeshift camps, a real humanitarian and health challenge. Our Parliament is right on target by emphasizing the plight of children. They are the first victims of the diphtheria epidemic, in particular, which raged in December. Doctors Without Borders is also sounding the alarm on their complete lack of access to education. Sorry to touch the icons here, but the silence of Aung San Suu Kyi, the Nobel Peace Prize winner and the current Minister of Foreign Affairs, is deafening! Ethnic cleansing, murders, this lost generation, rapes, prostitution ... His government must understand that we will not let go of the pressure.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I have not been to Myanmar or Bangladesh, but I know the scale of the tragedy there. The 700,000 Rohingya displaced persons who are currently in Bangladesh - more than half of whom are children - live in overcrowded camps, without hygiene, sanitation and security conditions and the million who remain in Myanmar - many of them in detention centers - it is even worse off after the expulsion of NGOs from that country. In addition to unhealthy conditions, malnutrition and post-traumatic stress, they now face, in the midst of monsoons, the risk of landslides, floods and the spread of diseases transmitted through water, such as typhus, diphtheria or hepatitis. If the true extent of the atrocities committed by the military of Myanmar will only be known after the full and unrestricted access to the raquine state of independent human rights organizations is allowed, the extremely harsh situation of these displaced persons today, to whom their country denies citizenship and that in Bangladesh they don't even have refugee status. The Union - which has provided more than EUR 40 million in humanitarian aid - cannot fail, in the face of this drama, to urge the Burmese authorities to allow the entry of international humanitarian organizations and to support efforts to implement the signed repatriation agreement.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, you know that in each plenary session of the European Parliament we spend time debating emergencies relating to massive and flagrant violations of human rights, which matter so much to the European Parliament because they must matter to the European Union. And, for the third time in a row, the question of the Rohingya, a community of 1,100,000 people, of which 650,000 have been violently displaced in recent times, half of them vulnerable women and children, crowded together in recent times, returns to this Parliament. overcrowded camps, in dramatic conditions that have been explained in all the languages ​​of the Union. 50,000 births are expected as a result of rape, in impossible conditions, absolutely intolerable from a humanitarian point of view. Therefore, what counts here is the Resolution that we are going to approve immediately, and that binds the Commission and that the Commission emphasize its commitment to human rights in its relationship with Myanmar and Bangladesh, in order, above all, to attend to this extremely vulnerable population, which is being persecuted for its membership of a religious community, one of the most binding and most prohibited reasons by international humanitarian law: to be discriminated against for their membership of a community.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the Rohingya tragedy continues. We have discussed the humanitarian crisis affecting these people at least seven times. This is a clear ethnic cleansing. It has economic bases, because they were essentially displaced, in order to seize their Earth where there are sources of wealth. It appears as a religious controversy of Buddhists against Muslims, as we have had in other cases Muslims against Christians. Basically the reasons are financial and we need to make that clear. But beyond that, at the moment more than 200,000 people are in camps and in danger, as we are in the era of the Monsoons, and in the facilities that remain there is now enormous pressure and phenomena prevail, such as oppression, prostitution, forced marriages. This situation must end and the European Union must put pressure on Myanmar.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, they threw my son up in the air and cut him in half with a machete. The story was told by Aisha, 19, Rohingya, whose seven-year-old son was killed by the Burmese Buddhist military while she and her family were fleeing their village in Myanmar. But Aisha and her child are not the only ones in this situation, at least a thousand Rohingya under the age of 5 have been brutally killed since last August. Twenty-eight thousand and three hundred are the children who have lost at least one parent. These innocent victims, arriving in the camps on the border with Bangladesh, face sexual abuse every day by the same militias that killed their parents. Even going to the bathroom or collecting wood is not safe for them. Added to this is the lack of food and water, sanitation and housing resistant to monsoon rains, increasing the risk of epidemics and making malnourished children particularly vulnerable. We therefore ask all competent authorities to guarantee children and women protected spaces in refugee camps and to authorize access to Rakhine for independent observers and the UN investigation mission. Instead I ask Europe: how can we continue to cooperate with a regime responsible for apartheid?

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman! Ladies and gentlemen! The Rohingya crisis is an extreme situation. New refugees are growing every day, among whom the percentage of women and children is growing. The overcrowded refugee camps do not have enough food, water or sanitation, and a solution to this situation seems difficult to achieve. All of this is due to Myanmar's dislike of the local community, which has manifested itself in the ethnic purge, which is described as "textbook" by the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights. The European Union should always intervene to defend the fundamental human rights that are clearly violated by the Rohingya people. Therefore, an immediate and stronger response from the international community is needed and the persecution of this people to an end as soon as possible. I believe that putting diplomatic and even economic pressure on the Myanmar authorities could start the process of the safe return of the Rohingya people.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, the EU is a powerful actor for human rights around the world: it is extraordinary, therefore, to see Brexiteers such as Mr Bashir and Mr Campbell Bannerman speaking from a platform they do not believe in. As a child rights campaigner, I’m appalled at the conditions in which Rohingya children are living. Their most basic rights are not respected and they suffer grave physical and psychological distress, as they have witnessed crimes against humanity. The situation of girls, in particular, is terrible: they face specific risks such as sexual violence and child marriage. Organisations present on the ground should adopt a gendered approach and take particular care of girls and women present in the refugee camps. I’m very grateful for the work that the UN, the NGOs and the EU do on the ground to provide these children with appropriate care and access to education, and I call on the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy to lead diplomatic efforts to find a peaceful solution, in order to bring an end to the violent discrimination against the Rohingya.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: – Mr President, the situation of the world’s most persecuted community is going way beyond any boundaries in a context of ethnic cleansing. In a situation of refugee camps where sexual violence and rape is prevalent, newborns are another extension of the Rohingya crisis which accelerates the vicious cycle of the current nightmare.  Indeed, 10 months since military violence forced hundreds of thousands of Rohingya to flee to Bangladesh, about 60 babies are being born every day in squalid refugee camps with greater health risks. A refugee camp is no place for a child to be born. Such camps have very poor sanitation and are a breeding ground for diseases like diphtheria, measles and cholera, to which newborns are particularly vulnerable. I strongly hope that the International Criminal Court’s Chief Prosecutor will confirm its jurisdiction over the crime of deportation of Rohingya people from Myanmar into Bangladesh, as its prosecutor has requested.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, the agreement of 6 June with the UN agencies on the repatriation of some of the Rohingya who fled from Myanmar into Bangladesh will not lead to a significant number of safe returns. Meanwhile, despite the very commendable efforts of Bangladesh, hundreds of thousands of people, including children, will continue to suffer. Most worryingly, just as the monsoon rains are coming, thousands of babies conceived in rape are expected to be born soon in the camps. Sexual violence was an integral tool of the Burmese military in its effort to inflict terror on the Rohingyas. Months after the height of the Burmese army’s atrocities, the suffering of these women continues, as they have to face not just a lack of access to healthcare services in the camps, but also exclusion from their deeply conservative families. The absolute priority is to save lives and to shelter these women and babies from the rains.

name: Miguel ARIAS CAÑETE
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me start by stressing that the European Union remains fully mobilised, politically and through extensive humanitarian and development assistance, to help to address the Rohingya refugee crisis. The European Union response to this crisis has consisted of five main components. First, immediate and unconditional humanitarian assistance to all displaced persons. Second, condemnation of all forms of violence. Third, continuous constructive engagement with the civilian Government of Myanmar on the basis of an ambitious development agenda, including with a view to addressing the root causes of conflict in accordance with the Annan report. Fourth, the promotion of conditions allowing the eventual voluntary and dignified return of displaced persons to their homes in Rakhine State in safety. And fifth, exploring assistance which goes beyond short-term aid. In all of this, due account has been taken of the relevant resolutions adopted by the European Parliament on the Rohingya crisis. This applies firstly in respect of action on the political front. As you know, the European Union has co-sponsored UN Human Rights Council resolutions to promote accountability and to invite Myanmar to cooperate with a UN fact-finding mission. We regret that Myanmar is not cooperating with this fact-finding mission. There is also continuing cooperation with the UN Special Rapporteur Ms Lee. In April 2018, in the light of the disproportionate use of force by the Myanmar army, the European Union adopted a strengthened arms embargo and put in place a framework for targeted restricted measures against Myanmar military officers. This being said, let me attend to the major issues of today’s debate: the situation of the Rohingya refugees and, in particular, the plight of children. As regards humanitarian and development aid, the European Union co-hosted – and pledged the highest contribution among all the donors at – the United Nations pledging conference on 23 October 2017. Our dialogue with Bangladesh authorities and the United Nations is constant in an effort to address the tremendous challenges faced by Bangladesh in welcoming the refugees generously. The monsoon season, which has just started, brings additional challenges and we are increasing our humanitarian aid in Bangladesh and continuing to provide aid in Rakhine State, but lack of access remains a key problem. Given the fact that the refugees’ return process will be difficult and long, and that the conditions for voluntary and safe return to the Rakhine State are not yet in place, the European Union and the international donor community must be prepared to work further on their humanitarian and development nexus, both for the refugees and for the 11 host communities in Bangladesh. Our humanitarian aid and development system does not specifically focus on children but, given the very high number of children and women in the camps, our aid actually does focus on these vulnerable groups of the refugee population. Let me highlight a couple of specific objectives that we are currently trying to achieve in cooperation with the Bangladesh Government and relevant stakeholders in Cox’s Bazar. The registration of newborn Rohingya babies should be pursued, as per the Memorandum of Understanding signed between Bangladesh and the UNCHR. And we are focusing on protection issues, including a security presence and security controls in the camps by law-enforcement authorities at all times. We are seeking authorisation to provide secondary education; we are looking into possibilities to support severely reliant families through local opportunities in order to avoid relations based on vulnerability; and we are pursuing preparedness initiatives in the context of the current monsoon and cyclone season, with a view to relocating the most vulnerable population to safer areas. The European Union will continue to provide support to the Rohingya people in Bangladesh in order to alleviate this major refugee crisis and to contribute to stabilisation in the region.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place after the debates end at12.00.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: in writing. - In the Kachin State, north-east of Burma, clashes have resumed between the Tatmadaw - the powerful Burmese army - and the Kachin Independence Army (Kia), the militia that for decades has safeguarded identity, land and traditions of the population, with a Christian majority. To demand an end to what is now a genocide of Christians, as well as a forgotten humanitarian crisis, thousands of Kachin Catholics marched through the streets of Myitkyina. Leading the march was the bishop of the city Francis Daw Tang. Many human rights organizations have denounced that the escalation of military operations by Burmese troops, against the groups that populate the country, is taking place, also thanks to the fact that international attention is focused on the Rohingya Muslim minority in the state. Rakhine. How does the High Representative intend to intervene to protect the Christian minority in Kachin? Does he also intend to raise this situation with the State Councilor and former Nobel Peace Prize winner, Aung San Suu Kyi?

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- I emphasize the duty of each state to prevent violence and instability, violations of order within the country.Migration and housing issues should be regulated in legal, peaceful ways, without violence, aggression and killing people, harming health.Any situation where people, especially children, are massacred or injured is reprehensible.I call on Myanmar to take immediate action in the context of Rohingya protection: to provide people with the necessary hygiene and health protection measures, and to provide medical and psychological assistance in refugee camps specifically for vulnerable groups.It is necessary to ensure the right of children to proper, regular education and training, to create favorable conditions for development, to actively combat violence, and to prevent the spread of crime.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The President has received a motion from the ALDE Group that Ms. Mirja Vehkaperä should be appointed as a member of the Development Committee and the delegation in the EU-Russia Parliamentary Cooperation Committee.No Comments?These names are thus confirmed.I have a point of order from Mr Bullmann.May I help you!

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: – Madam President, this Saturday is the second anniversary of the horrific murder of British Member of Parliament Jo Cox. Jo was a former staff member here in the European Parliament and colleagues remember her for her compassion, her openness and her determination to campaign for progressive change. Hatred, xenophobia and extremism have extinguished a bright spark in our political life.  While Jo was a member of our political family, she would work across the political spectrum, and so we should all take a moment to remember Jo Cox and the ideals for which she stood. As she told us, in her words, I quote: ‘We have far more in common with each other than things that divide us.’  Thank you President, thank you colleagues and thank you to Jo Cox, who will never be forgotten where European citizens meet.  (Loud applause)

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you, Mr. Bullmann!We will never forget all the people who fight and are committed to democracy, freedom and justice and have lost their lives or endured other suffering.It is good to keep reminding you of this.(Parliament stands up to honor the memory of Ms. Jo Cox.) Ms. Atkinson has spoken.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Madam President, I would like to raise an urgent human rights violation regarding the concerns for the safety of British citizen Tommy Robinson. Whether you agree with Tommy Robinson or his actions outside that court, he was jailed. He was safely serving his sentence in Hull prison. Yesterday, he was moved by the British Conservatives into a jail which has a high number of Muslim inmates.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Thank you, Mrs. Atkinson.This is not a point of order.I also have a point of order from Mrs Spinelli.(Heckling and unrest in the hall) I ask for your silence and let Mrs Spinelli speak.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have heard that the US military ship Trenton saved forty-one people from a shipwreck near Libya.I said, listen to me is a matter of life ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Dear colleagues, dear colleagues!From now on, whenever a point of order is raised, I shall ask that the rule of procedure be mentioned first.(Applause)

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item on the agenda is the vote.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: – Madam President, according to Rule 59a of the Rules of Procedure, I ask Parliament to refer this proposal back to the Committee on Transport and Tourism for interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, addressing myself to my colleagues and especially those MEPs who want to challenge the mandate: it is always easy to punish all for the crimes of some. Not all transport companies are misusing their workers. Not all transport companies are doing illegal or unfair market access. Sadly, our usual solution is a collective penalty but in Mobility Package I we have, together, been able to find solutions to the biggest social and unfair competition problems, without a huge bureaucratic burden and without major collective penalties and still keeping a balance in the internal market. Cabotage caused problems inside Member States in national transport. Now, we are limiting it to two days per Member State and it will be posting from day one. Nomadic driving: drivers have a new right to go back home by the end of a maximum of three weeks. We are ending driver misuse and letter box companies. For the first time, common strong enforcement is possible by using the latest technology available. If the national transport is posting from day one, colleagues voting against can go back home and tell drivers that in the future they might not drive for their national salaries anymore. Instead, they could be paid a final country destination minimum wage.  This is a two—way street. You need to understand what it means for the universally applicable collective agreements if you oppose the mandate. Minimum wages might become the new norm and you should all be aware of that. Currently, we do not have a common EU minimum wage level in transport and the posting of the Drivers Directive is not the right tool to do that. That is totally another discussion. I urge you to take a responsible decision and vote in favour of the mandates of all three files.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!Why is?No more and no less than that this part of the mobility package should be dealt with not just in committee but in plenary.What are we actually afraid of?Is it so unusual for contentious issues to be dealt with in plenary?If we no longer want that, if we no longer want all elected MEPs to have a say, let us abolish the plenary completely and only use committee votes as a basis for negotiations!In addition to two extreme proposals - always inside and always outside - there were also real compromises on the posting of workers in the international transport sector, and that is exactly what I want to have dealt with in plenary.No more and no less.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: A point of order - on what basis please?

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: – Madam President, I want to ask Mr Koch why he voted in favour in the committee.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: We are no longer in the debate, Mr Marinescu, but in the vote.We cannot reopen the debate.We have now heard someone for and someone against, and we are moving on to the roll-call vote.

name: Wim van de CAMP
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, this is the second part of Mobility Package I. After the posting of Ms Merja Kyllönen, we will have now driving and rest times for the drivers. To be honest, I have to fight today against fake news.  In this proposal, the actual driving and rest times of the drivers are not being changed. Everybody is giving us information that we are changing the driving and rest times, which is fake news. We are improving the labour and working circumstances and conditions of the drivers, and with our proposal a driver has to go home after the second week – so he goes home in the third week.  If you look at what is happening now with nomadic drivers, who stay away from home for seven or eight weeks, this is really an improvement in the drivers’ labour circumstances.  We will also give drivers the opportunity to spend their weekly and their daily rest times in proper parking places where there are toilets, the possibility to take a shower and possibilities to eat. This is not a small detail, this is the truth. And in addition to this, the enforcement of this regulation by the smart tachograph will be improved in 2024.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: – Madam President, I would like to say to Mr van der Camp that that was a very interesting speech for next plenary but Mr van der Camp, let me just give you the arguments why our Group will oppose the mandate, and it has nothing to do with the work of the people in the Committee on Transport and Tourism – Mr van der Camp and the other shadow rapporteurs. It has to do with a very important argument on democracy.  This is about the working conditions of more than one and a half million truckers in our Europe and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs has had a vote as well and it was a different vote. So it is important that we can express ourselves as a plenary, all together, and that is why we will oppose this mandate. (Applause)

name: Karima DELLI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, as we can see, the subject of road freight transport is an extremely sensitive subject on which the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs and the Committee on Transport and Tourism have expressed their views. of this Parliament. And it is clear that today, both have expressed strongly divergent views on these three issues.
