For understandable practical reasons, we believe that it is high time and of the utmost importance that the plenary, that is to say all of you, be able to pronounce on all these files. , but also on the question of cabotage. We need to adopt a position that reflects the full diversity of our assembly on the social reform of road freight transport and in particular on the issue of cabotage. I therefore ask you to be above the fray and to vote against this mandate and to open the possibility for our assembly to vote at the next plenary in July.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, I have to say that I like Karima very much – she is our Chair – but in that sense she is not right – I have to say that. Why? Because we have found a good compromise, a compromise between most of the Groups within Parliament. We have worked for weeks on this compromise, and when you look at the signature and also at the decision which has been taken in the shadow meetings and in the Committee on Transport and Tourism, we found a big majority, and this is the difference with the two dossiers which we have voted on before. On cabotage there is a big majority within Parliament and also within the Committee, therefore it wouldn’t make any sense to challenge this dossier also. This is totally different. We have a balanced approach and we have been successful, therefore I support it and I would like to invite you to vote in favour and not send it back.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The voting time is now closed.

name: Rory PALMER
text: – Madam President, this report concerns itself with financial barriers to culture, and for me, culture includes football. There are many financial barriers to people who want to go and watch football, particularly children and young people. So I believe it’s time more was done by the football authorities to make ticket prices affordable both at club and international level. We should not see international matches in national stadiums like Wembley in qualifying rounds and friendlies being played when the crowd is only filling half the stadium or less. The Football Association and our national football associations should do more to fill those seats and give those tickets away to young people through schools. And at club level, let me congratulate two of the most famous football clubs in the world in my region, who are leading the way in this: Notts County, who made tickets available for GBP 2 to people a few months ago, and to Nottingham Forest, who are making season tickets available for GBP 10 to young people for the coming season.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I supported the CULT own-initiative report and thank my colleague Zdrojewski for its excellent work. The starting point is the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, which includes the right of access to culture, and I consider this to be an important value. The report rightly addresses what hinders greater access to culture, especially for disadvantaged groups. It is also looking for solutions for culture in the age of advancing digitization, for accessibility and quality. A special area is devoted to the financing of culture, which is primarily on the shoulders of the Member States. But the EU can make a significant contribution with its funds and programs. We will soon be discussing the Creative Europe program for the next financial period until 2027. For this program, the Commission is proposing to increase funding to EUR 1.85 billion for 7 years. I think we need to support this increase. The creative sector in Europe is very strong and means great employment and growth for Europe.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - It is important to raise the issue of structural and financial barriers to access to culture as negotiations on the next multiannual financial framework begin. In the current programming period, the European Union spends only 0.15% of its budget on culture. Although Europe is known for its rich culture and cultural and historical heritage, there is currently no adequate funding for the cultural sector at European Union level. Things are the same nationally. Culture is only talked about during elections. Then there is silence, and one of the main reasons people do not attend cultural events is the lack of funds. Although the government is aware of this obstacle in Bulgaria, they still believe that young people do not need a cultural check, and if we ourselves do not have a valuable national policy in the field of culture, European funding can not help us.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: - Madam President, I supported the report because I consider it very important. Access to culture is one of the fundamental rights guaranteed in many legal instruments, but there are nevertheless many barriers to accessing and participating in culture. We can already overcome structural obstacles, which can be defined as geographical, which is the distance from the centers of cultural life, such as theaters, museums, libraries, cinemas or cultural centers. Digital barriers are no longer an acute problem either, as digital literacy is well ahead. The most important obstacle is the financial one. The European Union budget, which is very embarrassing to culture, also contributes to this. But individual Member States should also contribute more in their budgets to a culture that unites, educates, educates people, prevents social exclusion and, last but not least, creates new jobs. Culture must become a part of life from an early age of every inhabitant. I would draw particular attention to measures to improve access to culture for people with disabilities.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, inclusivity and diversity have become our obsession. Everything is measured against this one yardstick, so that it becomes the primary purpose of every institution. A university isn’t there to teach; it is there to have a representative intake. A company board isn’t there to defend the interests of shareholders; it’s there to look like the rest of society. A parliament isn’t there to represent the opinions of the voters, but to resemble them physically. And of course, it’s no surprise that we’re extending our thinking into the field of culture. Even so, isn’t there something just a little bit redolent of an insecure dictatorship that we’re now making culture the business of politicians? Wasn’t European culture in full flower for centuries before the state started trying to regulate it? In fact, wasn’t every attempt at state patronage a repression of the truly creative instinct? I wonder whether we’re aware of how this comes across? Surely we should hold ourselves to a higher standard than some tin-pot country that defines its national greatness in terms of state-controlled cultural activity?

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo mar is dóigh liom go bhfuil na moltaí atá inti an-mhaith ar fad.  Dar leis na Náisiúin Aontaithe is ceart daonna é go mbeadh teacht ar chultúr - ceann de na cearta go mba chóir a bheith ag chuile duine ar domhan. Ach, feicimid gurb iad na daoine is saibhre is mó a bhfuil teacht acu ar shaol cultúrtha.  Agus is trua sin, mar a lán de na tairgí cultúrtha is luachmhaire ar domhan tháinig siad ó dhaoine bochta, a bhí an-bhocht agus a bhí thíos leis ar ais nó ar éigean.  Mar shampla, dar leis an Eorabharaiméadar agus Eurostat, ní théann 25% de dhaoine go dtí ceolchoirmeacha de bharr easpa airgid; 22% de bharr easpa airgid, ní théann siad go dtí an phictiúrlann; an amharclann 20%, agus ballet agus damhsaí 14%. Agus labhair an tUasal Palmer ar chúrsaí peile. Dá bhrí sin is cabhair an-mhór í an tuarascáil seo.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, culture is one of the primary goods, and cultural access and participation are considered a priority issue at EU level. The current work plan for culture for the period 2015-2018 adopted by the European Council in 2014 mentions assessable and inclusive culture as our top priority. However, nowadays we face several obstacles to cultural access and participation. There are not only structural and financial barriers to access, but also social and digital barriers, and by far the most important problem of educational barriers. To overcome these hurdles it is necessary to develop firstly public funding, then sustainable and long-term cultural tourism policy, then coordination of national cultural policies (I have to say), and digital education. And therefore I call, after the vote, on the European Union within the sphere of its competence to develop and implement specific measures in order to guarantee access and participation in cultural life.

name: Dobromir SOŚNIERZ
text: - Madam President! I voted against. This is another redundant regulation. There is no reason whatsoever for the state to meddle in the field of culture. A moment ago, one of the MEPs who justify before me led the situation to absurdity by demanding funding for football as part of helping culture. Really, what else do you need? Perhaps we should finance chariot races, this forgotten sport, which is limping in our country at the moment, and for someone maybe striptease will be a form of culture, maybe we should finance strip bars. The right to culture means the right to spend your money as you wish, on whatever form of culture you feel is appropriate. Producing some crap by artists on behalf of the state just to please officials is a distortion of culture, it is making creators dependent on state funding and destroying creativity. Because officials, if they were good culture experts, would be busy creating culture, not shifting papers. Therefore, I protest against the interference of the Union in other areas of life without any need.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of the trialogue agreement on the proposal for a directive on the adequacy test before the adoption of the new occupational legislation.A common framework for assessing proportionality will increase the transparency and predictability of national regulation.At the same time, the quality and standard of safety for the performance of specific professions must remain ensured.More transparent rules will then facilitate the possibility for EU citizens to pursue regulated professions in another Member State.The framework for carrying out the proportionality test will thus be clearly defined and at the same time will not be too complicated from a procedural point of view and will thus not lead to unnecessary administrative burdens.I therefore consider it right for Member States to have some discretion in assessing whether it is appropriate to consult stakeholders before introducing new rules.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: - Madam President, the regulation of access to the professions is still a matter for the Member States, and it is therefore up to the national authorities to determine their conditions. But at the same time, Member States must respect the principles of non-discrimination and proportionality. The report we have approved today sets out the criteria that a Member State must meet when evaluating its measures. We want all Member States to have comparable conditions and to make the evaluation more transparent and involve all stakeholders in the decision-making process. As regulated professions such as doctors, engineers and architects play a key role in the European economy, it is important that they have clear and transparent conditions in the performance of their activities. The way in which the Member States regulate these conditions must be transparent and predictable throughout Europe. I am therefore pleased that, with this report, which I supported, we will define clear rules that will thus contribute to the protection of public health, the protection of consumers, the recipients of these services, as well as workers in the various sectors.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I fully support this proposal to create a standard framework for professional qualification requirements across the European Union. By creating a pan-European framework, it will make it much easier for professional qualifications awarded by one Member State to be recognised in another Member State, thus creating free movement across the European Union. It is my opinion that this introduction will strengthen the reliability, transparency and compatibility of professional requirements between Member States across the Union. A proportionality test is important to gain insight into the effect that this new regulation could have in professions across the European Union. I support this introduction, as it is fundamental that we must safeguard the professions and those who have undertaken an enormous amount of work to reach their qualification. Although I agree that an expansion of this great single market is important, and indeed desirable, I also understand it must be done in a measured and sensible manner, and then we will do it right.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, in August it will be ten years since Russia’s aggression towards Georgia. We all know what happened then. Lives were claimed; Russia seized part of Georgia’s territory; many became internally-displaced persons. And now, ten years after the conflict, there is still only limited hope that we will soon reach an agreement and a resolution to that conflict. Quite the opposite: Russia continues contracting new bases, bringing in new troops, putting fences and barbed wire across new parts of the region, and we let it happen. The EU should never forget Georgia, because what is at stake is the belief that the international community should respect the territorial integrity of all states and should respect international law. This is why the EU must do the utmost to urge Russia to implement its commitments undertaken under the six-point peace plan and stop violating the sovereignty of Georgia.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, this year marks the 10th anniversary of Russia's invasion of Georgia and the ongoing occupation of the Georgian regions of Abkhazia and South Ossetia.We had a very detailed discussion about it here.I supported and signed this resolution and call for support for Georgia and its sovereignty.I also call on the politicians of the EU countries to support the boycott of the World Cup in Russia, which is starting today, by politicians, which is very symbolic.Of course, neither athletes nor fans can blame the organization for a bad decision.Recall that it was less than two weeks after the end of the Olympics in Sochi, Russia invaded Crimea.We can ask ourselves what will happen after the end of the championship.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President! Dear colleagues! As rapporteur here in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on Georgia, I want to say that, of course, this resolution is a very important political step - a sign not only for Georgia but also for the whole world, that is clear. But what I extremely dislike about the text of the resolution and the way in which the debate went, which I actually said during the debate, is that we forget people. That is the most important thing. For what our resolutions exist, if not for people, as they say, "on the ground". For example, territorial indivisibility, integrity is an official position of the European Parliament, the European Commission, the European Union. But if Abkhazia and South Ossetia are legally part of Georgia, then we must think of the people who live in Abkhazia and South Ossetia, because they are citizens of Georgia. That is what we sometimes do not see here when debating resolutions. An important document, but we must go further.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I would like to stress that our main task as representatives of the European Union is not to preach and sermonise to the African, Caribbean and Pacific group of states about how to build and govern their states, but to give them reliable support. In order to build strong partnership relations and bonds between the EU and the ACP, we need to gain their trust and ensure that European companies do not violate the rights of the indigenous population of the ACP. Our political dialogue must be balanced and based on mutual respect and trust first of all. Moreover, the renewed EU and ACP cooperation and partnership should ensure more effective joint action to tackle the various challenges facing the world today, such as combating terrorism and, first of all, organised crime. I voted in favour, of course.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the large question for written answer with debate by Patrick Le Hyaric, Martina Michels, Paloma López Bermejo, Ángela Vallina, Tania González Peñas, Sofia Sakorafa, Marisa Matias, Josu Juaristi Abaunz, Martina Anderson, Matt Carthy, Lynn Boylan, Liadh Ní Riada, Eleonora Forenza, João Ferreira, Joao Pimenta Lopes, Miguel Viegas, Younous Omarjee, Xabier Benito Ziluaga, Javier Couso Permuy, Curzio Maltese, Lola Sánchez Caldentey, Luke Ming Flanagan, Barbara Spinis Takis Hadjigeorgiou, Marina Albiol Guzmán, Marie-Christine Vergiat, Neoklis Sylikiotis, Merja Kyllönen, Kostadinka Kuneva, Maria Lidia Senra Rodríguez, Miguel Urbán Crespo, Helmut Scholz, Marie-Pierre Vieu, Dimitrios Papadimoulis, Stelios Kouloglou, Torresine Martefanís to the Commission: Israel's participation in projects funded by the Horizon 2020 program (O-000014/2018 - B8-0028 / 2018) (20 18/2721 (RSP)). Unfortunately, the Commissioner has been delayed due to traffic problems, but unfortunately we cannot wait any longer. I think it will be there in a few minutes. May I give the floor to the author of the great question, Mr Le Hyaric, for five minutes.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: author. - Mr President, our questioning aims to ask for a precise assessment of the conformity not only with our values, but also with the European law of cooperation with the Israeli government within the framework of the Horizon 2020 program. The United Nations Committee against Torture has denounced Israel's use of torture and illegal and abusive technologies during interrogations by Israeli police and prison staff; Moreover, the Israeli Constitutional Court had also raised this question. However, the so-called Lawtrain project, which receives European funding of more than 5 million euros, involves the Israeli ministry of public security, which manages prisons and decides on entry and exit from the territory. This project aims to improve police interrogation techniques. This therefore places us, as we choose, in illegality or in an intolerable complicity. This is the analysis of the Portuguese ministry and the Belgian University Leuven, which withdrew from the project. We must now get out of the chiaroscuro veil that hides what, in research, is civilian and what is military, when it is known that so-called civilian applications include areas related to security, the national police, border guards, cybersecurity or airport security. There is a need to clarify the role of several Israeli companies that benefit from the funding, such as Mellanox, which is experimenting with the occupation, Elbit Systems, one of Israel's largest arms factories making banned cluster bombs, or IsraTeam, client of the Israeli army. On the other hand, the Union's financial regulations require applicants to be excluded from all European funding - I quote - "if it has been established by a final judgment or a final administrative decision that the economic operator has committed a serious professional misconduct, by having violated applicable legislative or regulatory provisions or the ethical standards of the profession to which he belongs ”; I am referring here to Article 106, paragraph 1. However, the Israeli Ministry of Public Security, which controls the prisons, carries out the deportation and detention of Palestinian prisoners on Israeli territory, therefore outside the territories of the Occupied Palestine, in violation of Article 76 of the Fourth Geneva Convention, yet ratified by Israel in 1951. We ask the European Commission to assess the serious and repeated breaches by the Israeli Ministry of Security of the provisions of Article 106 of the financial regulations of the European Union, of the International Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment, of the Statute of the International Criminal Court, of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union and of the Fourth Convention of Geneva, before continuing this project. Given the conditions of detention of Palestinian prisoners, the occupation of Palestine, the destruction of humanitarian and educational infrastructure funded by the European Union, the failure to comply with UN resolutions, the Commission must decide on a suspension of all our partnership projects. I await a response from the Commission in this regard.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mr President, Israel is an excellent example of the successful implementation of Horizon 2020. It certainly has its own big scientific and technical potential, and our program may play a secondary role in the development of the Israeli knowledge-based industry. But for other countries in the European Neighborhood Policy (ENP), this program may be essential. It can help to develop life-saving technologies and substances that the countries of the southern Mediterranean especially need. I am happy that Horizon was included in November 2017 as one of the parts of the ‘ENP plus’ strategy. This will allow us to extend the areas where the interests of the EU and those of the ENP countries overlap. In the case of Israel, this program enables it to, firstly, integrate with the European academic research community; secondly, cooperate with key players in Europe; and thirdly, have access to research infrastructure and attention in order to have an influence on European norms. This is very attractive for our neighbors and profitable to us. Certainly I find it one of the best successes of the EU’s normative power. We cooperate with our neighbors and allow them to have a say in development inside the EU. This is a unique situation. No other power in the world does it. I will continue in Latvian, the language of my country. Sometimes we often hear criticism of Israel, which was also mentioned by the honorable author of the question, but in reality Israel is one of the countries that may not be geographically closest to the European Union, but closest to us in terms of our values. Because there is and Israel is based on the same democratic values ​​that the European Union is based on. I cannot agree that human rights violations are as serious as the author mentioned, especially with regard to prisoners. What I mean by that is that Israel is a country where human rights issues are very carefully respected. However, given the conflict that has been going on for so long in modern history, Israel is actually using our European system to respect human rights. Sometimes, when it comes to my political group, the Socialists and Democrats, we get the impression that we have a 'pro-Palestinian' position. This is partly a fact, because we are actively cooperating with the Palestinian parties, but on the other hand, I would like to say that we very much appreciate what Israel is doing, especially - I will repeat it again and again - in the field of human rights. I can mention that Arabic also has the status of an official language in Israel. This is important when it comes to my country, Latvia, where historically many national minorities live. And the example of Israel, not only when it comes to Horizon 2020, but in general, judging by the level of democracy in Israel, we can learn a lot from the state system, from the level of democracy, from the parliamentary democracy that is in Israel. We need to take this background into account when we talk about further cooperation, and in particular in the area of ​​neighborhood policy. To sum up, I would like to say that we have great prospects for cooperation with Israel, and not just in this area. Israel is a country with a long enough tradition of democracy and enough luggage that Israel has piled up in terms of democracy and human rights. And I really see a very big perspective in this cooperation.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! I regret there is no commissioner. This is an important debate, Israel is our important partner, it is the leader when it comes to innovation in the world, according to Bloomberg, it is in the first place, and the Commissioner should be here. I understand traffic jams, but they are predictable in Strasbourg. Let us leave the commissioner. I have such an impression (and I have been in the European Parliament for fourteen years) that there is a certain fashion here among some circles. The fashion is to criticize Israel, often in isolation from certain facts. I believe that you need to have a dialogue with Israel. You can have different opinions - and you have to have different opinions sometimes - but let's be objective. We are talking about certain regulations that are beneficial to the European Union and also to the area of ​​European innovation and technology. This is a benefit. On the issue of human rights, let me be very honest: it seems to me that a dozen or so years ago Israel had the same policy as it does today, and then it was not so criticized, also here in the European Parliament, and is now often criticized very harshly. . Has anything changed in the European Union during this time? I think so, but I have the impression that it is not Israel that has changed, but that the European Union is changing in terms of its attitude towards Israel. And I don't know if this is a positive change. I think not. We are talking about human rights in Israel here, and that's good. Of course, we can talk about anything. However, I would like to point out that the police in Israel are under judicial supervision, it is not a state within a state. It is worth talking about it, it is worth knowing about it, and not presenting a certain - as it seems to me - one-sided narrative or vision of this situation. In closing, I appeal to us to exercise moderation and common sense here, and to continue these relations. This is good for our side, for the EU side. And it is very important. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: blue card issue.- Thank you, Ryszard Czarnecki, for accepting my blue card question.We know the difficult history that existed in Poland when it comes to the Jewish community in your country.We know the 'ugly' pages in the history of my country's history book in Latvia and what you said that we are changing here in the European Union with regard to Israel.Do you see an element of anti-Semitism in some attacks on Israel?

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- I remember the meeting of the Prime Minister of Israel - it was in the Knesset in December 2016 - with a delegation of colleagues from the European Parliament.The same question was asked about anti-Semitism in Europe, and Prime Minister Netanyahu said that he mainly saw anti-Semitism, indeed, but in Western Europe and not in our region.Let me be honest here: I have a personal thread, because my grandmother was the person who saved Jews during World War II, and I will always remember about her during such discussions.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Club. - Mr. Chairman, I had the opportunity to visit Israel on a number of occasions, I had the opportunity to work with companies that had high technology, with companies that deal with the aviation industry and, by coincidence, because of the aviation industry, of course, I had the opportunity to meet other very sophisticated companies. and he was personally convinced of what Israel means when we talk about research, when we talk about development and when we talk about cooperation with the member states of the European Union. I think we need to consider a lot of things before we make our final decisions, because one thing is for sure - I am not thrilled with everything that the Israeli government is doing, to be completely clear. On the other hand, it is certain that we cannot go into a break-up abruptly and in this way as suggested. I agree and want and ask the commission to review all the regulations, whether all the decisions made are based on our regulations that we have made ourselves; never enough control, in fact - let's review everything once again, whether we are doing everything right, but I am not in favor of ending the cooperation in this way and with the arguments presented here. I think that we could do more damage to ourselves, precisely because of the fact that there is excellent scientific cooperation between universities, between scientists, that there is also excellent economic cooperation, we have to talk about it very clearly and openly. So I believe that setting things up like this is not the solution. The solution is certainly to talk to the Israeli government, to politicians in Israel, to warn them of those things that we do not like, but we cannot escape the fact that Israel is not a state governed by the rule of law, that it does not respect human rights, so there are extremists here. , in this Parliament, if you will. And there and there, because I listen to them and I, like you here, and that's why I wouldn't want, so to speak, not to see a tree from the forest. I think we have to be really wise, smart and careful here, with a request to the Commission to do the job once again, respecting of course your political group, because that is the request of one political group. If so, the Commission must do its job, but I call for seriousness and responsibility in moments like this.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, if we question Israel’s participation in the Horizon 2020 program, we would be making three mistakes. A fault against science: Israel, a small country in size, the only democracy in its region, has succeeded in developing brilliantly in a hostile environment. As tech mogul Elon Musk recently said, Israel has moved beyond a "start-up nation" to become a true technological powerhouse on par with the United States. This desire to survive, to innovate and to master its destiny is an example for Europeans, for our States and an opportunity for our researchers and our companies. By ideology, would we like to deprive them of it? You don't stop scientific progress with dark good feelings. This obscurantism which leads us to refuse scientific cooperation which goes in the direction of our interests. Is it because Israel is a successful example of technology and civil-military synergies? Knowing that 80% of civilian innovations come from defense - the RDS system, station search, the internet, ABS - I could name a whole host of technologies that come solely from defense. We would also be committing a fault against peace. By isolating Israel and taking up the rhetoric of the Palestinian radicals, we will not serve peace. We would go along with Palestinian sectarian interests and push them to radicalize. Do we have these same qualms when it comes to the funds allocated by the European Union to the Palestinian Authority, which are also used, it must be said, to manufacture bombs and missiles against Israel? How can we draw the parallel between Israel and apartheid South Africa? We would be committing a third fault against the Member States. Need I remind you that it is not for Europe to tell us with whom the states should cooperate, with what projects? Europe would once again step out of its role of European coordination to take on skills that it does not have, that do not belong to it. The Union is a coup, too often, to weaken member states. Moreover, by playing with the Israeli-Palestinian conflict, we risk stoking the fire in the suburbs of our member states with high Muslim immigration, where anti-Zionism is often the mask of anti-Semitism and hatred of our countries of the world. 'Home. Is it because Israel is such a hated model of a nation-state in this place that we allow ourselves to teach it lessons? Our irresponsibility would lead Europe to diplomatic and technological isolation. (The speaker agrees to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. Mamikins had a question.I do not have a question.I just want to ask you something, Mr President.It is not possible that the Commissioner is not here.Mr Moedas must be given a red card, not a blue card, a red card for Commissioner Moedas.Please do that. Mr Mamikins probably has the question.Sorry again.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I take that as a point of order.And I assume that Mr Schaffhauser will accept a question from Mr Mamikins just as he would have accepted it from Mr Jakovčić.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: , blue card issue.- Thank you, Mr Schaffhauser, for accepting my blue card question.I have to say that one thing is that the Commissioner does not want to come to work, another thing is that because of transport and other problems, a person cannot come to the European Parliament on time, but that is the way it is.You said Mr Schaffhauser about scientific cooperation.I had a great opportunity, when I was a journalist, to ask Shimon Peres, the President of Israel, and he said that science knows no bounds.Where do you see opportunities for scientific cooperation with the European Union and Israel at the moment?

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: response "blue card".- I am obviously very much in favor of this cooperation, not only with the States of the European Union but also with the Union as such.I believe that the program that the Union carried out in the framework research agreement which was launched in 1996 has been fruitful for both parties, since if I read my notes correctly, Israel has, thanks to this, invested 1, 3 billion euros and received 1.7 billion euros.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Ladies and gentlemen!I have no requests to speak on the procedure for spontaneous requests to speak.I will inform the President and ask him how we proceed on this matter.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: I declare the session of the European Parliament adjourned.
